div.p: A comedy presented before the King's majesty at Cambridge, the ninth of march, 1614.
By the gentlemen of Trinity college.
London, printed by Nicholas Okes for Walter burr, and are to be sold at his shop, in Paul's churchyard. 1615.

sp.l: The brightness of so great and fair a presence,
They say, strikes cold amazement. But I feel
Contrary effects. For from the gracious centre
O'th honourable assembly, some secret power
Inflames my courage; and, methinks , I am grown
Taller by th'virtue of this audience.
And yet thus raised, I fear there's no retiring.
Ladies, whose beauties glad the whole assembly,
Upon your favours I impose my business.
If't be a fault to speak this foreign language,
(For Latin is our mother tongue) I must entreat you
To frame excuses for us; for whose sake
We now speak English. All the rest, we hope,
Come purposely to grace our poor endeavours;
As we to please. In whose fair courtesy
We trust; not in our weak ability.

div.head: Scoen. 1.

sp.speaker: Albumazar.
sp.l: Come brave mercurials sublimed in cheating,
My dear companions, fellow-soldiers
I'th watchful exercise of thievery:
Shame not at your so large profession,
No more than I at deep astrology.
For in the days of old, good morrow thief,
As welcome was received, as now your worship.
The Spartans held it lawful, and th'arabians,
So grew Arabia, foelix; Sparta valiant.

sp.speaker: Ronc.
sp.l: Read on this lecture, wise Albumazar.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Your patron Mercury in his mysterious character,
Holds all the marks of th'other wanderers,
And with his subtle influence works in all,
Filling their storeys full of robberies.
Most trades and callings much participate
Of yours; though smoothly gilt with th'honest title
Of merchant, lawyer, or such like: the learned
Only excepted; and he's therefore poor.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.l: And yet he steals one author from another.
This poet is that poet's plagiary,
and he a third's, till they end all in Homer.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: And Homer filched all from an Egyptian priestess.
The world's a theater of theft. Great rivers
Rob smaller brooks; and them the ocean.
And in this world of ours, this microcosm:
Guts from the stomach steal, and what they spare,
The meseraicks filch, and lay't i'th liver:
Where (Lest it should be found) turned to red nectar,
'Tis by a thousand thievish veins conveyed
And hid in flesh, nerves, bones, muscles and sinews,
In tendons, skin and hair, so that the property
Thus altered, the theft can never be discovered.
Now all these pilferies couched and composed in order,
Frame thee and me. Man's a quick mass of the every.

sp.speaker: Ronc.
sp.l: Most philosophical Albumazar!

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.l: I thought these parts had lent and borrowed mutual.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Say they do so: 'tis done with full intention
Ne'er to restore, and that's flat robbery.
Therefore go on: follow your virtue's laws
Your Cardinal virtue, great necessity,
Wait on her close, with all occasions.
Be watchful, have as many eyes as heaven,
And ears as harvest: be resolved and impudent,
Believe none, trust none: for in this city
(As in a fought field crows and carcases)
No dwellers are but cheaters and cheatees.

sp.speaker: Ronc.
sp.l: If all the houses in the town were prisons,
The chambers cages, all the settles stocks,
The broad gates gallows, and the whole people
Justices, juries, constables, keepers and hangmen,
I'd practise spite of all, and leave behind me
A fruitful seminary of our profession,
And call them by thy name Albumazarians.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.l: And I no less, were all the city thieves
As cunning as thyself.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Why bravely spoken,
Fitting such generous spirits: I'll make way
To your great virtue with a deep resemblance.
Of high astrology. Harpax and Ronca
List to our profit: I have new lodged a prey
Hard by, that taken is so fat and rich
'Twill make us leave off trading, and fall to purchase.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.l: Who is't? speak quickly.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Where good Albumazar?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: 'Tis a rich gentleman, as old as foolish.
Th'poor remnant of whose brain that age had left him
The doting love of a young girl hath dried:
And which concerns us most, he gives firm credit
To necromancy and astrology,Enter Furbo.
Sending to me, as one that promise both.
Pandolfo is the man.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: What old Pandolfo?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: The same: but stay, yon's Furbo whose smoothest brow
Shines with good news, and's visage promises
Triumphs and trophies to's. Furbo plays.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: My life has learned out all, I know't by's music;
Bear up thy learned brow Albumazar,
Live long of all the world admired,
For art profound, and skill retired
To cheating by the height of stars.
Hence, gypsies, hence, hence rogues of baser strain,
That hazard life for little gain:
Stand off and wonder, gape and gaze afar
At the rare skill of great Albumazar.

sp.speaker: Furb.
sp.l: Albumazar,
Spread out thy nets at large, here's foul abundance:
Pandolfo's ours, I understand his business
Which I filched closely from him, while he revealed
T'his man, his purposes and projects.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Excellent!
Thanks to this instrument: for in pretence
Of teaching young Sulpitia, th'old man's daughter,
I got access to th'house, and while I waited
Till she was ready, overheard Pandolfo
Open his secrets to his servant: thus 'tis.
Antonio, Pandolfo's friend, and neighbour,
Before he went to Barbary, agreed
To give in marriage.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Furbo, this no place
Fit to consider curious points of business.
Come let's away, I'll hear't at large above.
Ronca stay you below, and entertain him
With a loud noise of my deep skill in art.
Thou knowest my rosy modesty cannot do it.
Harpax up you, and from my bedchamber,
Where all things for our purposes are ready,
Second each beck, and nod, and word of ours.
You know my meaning.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: Yes sir.

div.stage: Furbo goes out singing, fa la la Pandolfo's ours.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: There's old Pandolfo, amorous as youthful may,
And grey as January. I'll attend him here.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Cricca, I seek thy aid, not thy cross counsel,
I am mad in love with Flavia, and must have her:
Thou spend'st thy reasons to the contrary,
Like arrows 'gainst an anvil: I love Flavia,
And must have Flavia.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Sir you have no reason,
She's a young girl of sixteen, you of sixty.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I have no reason, nor spare room for any,
Love's harbinger hath chalked upon my heart,
And with a coal writ on my brain, for Flavia;
This house is wholly taken up for Flavia.
Let reason get a lodging with her wit:
Vex me no more, I must have Flavia.

sp.speaker: Cric.
sp.l: But sir, her brother Lelio, under whose charge
She's now, after her father's death, sware boldly
Pandolfo never shall have Flavia.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: His father, ere he went to Barbary,
Promised her me: who be he live or dead,
spite of a last of Lelio's ▪ Pandolfo
Shall enjoy Flavia.

sp.speaker: Cric.
sp.l: Sir you're too old.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I must confess in years about three score,
But in tough strength of body, four and twenty,
Or two months less. Love of young Flavia,
More powerful than Medea's drugs, renews
All decayed parts of man: my arteries
Blown full with youthful spirits, move the blood
To a new business: my withered nerves grow plump
And strong, longing for action. Hence thou poor prop
Of feebleness and age: walk with such sires
As with cold palsies shake away their strength,
And lose their legs with cureless gouts. Pandolfo
New moulded is for revels, masks, and music. Cricca,
String my neglected lute, and from my armoury
Scour my best sword, companion of my youth,
Without which I seem naked.

sp.speaker: Cric.
sp.l: Your love, sir, like strong water
To a deplored sick man, quicks your feeble limbs
For a poor moment. But after one night's lodging
You'll fall so dull and cold, that Flavia
Will shriek and leap from bed as from a sepulchre.
Shall I speak plainer, sir? She'll cuckold you:
Alas she'll cuckold you.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: What me? A man of known discretion,
Of riches, years, and this grey gravity?
I'll satisfy'r with gold, rich clothes and jewels.

sp.speaker: Cric.
sp.l: Wert not far fitter urge your son Eugenio
To woo her for himself?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Cricca be gone,
Touch no more there: I will and must have Flavia.
Tell Lelio, if he grant m'his sister Flavia,
I'll give my daughter to him in exchange.
Be gone, and find me here within this half hour.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: 'Tis well that servant's gone: I shall the easier
Wind up his master to my purposes.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Sure this some novice of th'artillery,
That winks and shoots: sir, prime your piece anew
The powder's wet: tick. tock. tick. tock.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: A good ascendent bless me: sir are you frantic?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Why frantic? are not knocks the lawful courses
T'open doors and ears?

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Of vulgar men and houses.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Whose lodging's this? is't not th'astrologers?

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: His lodging? no: 'tis the learned phrontisterion
Of most divine Albumazar.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Good sir,
If the door break, a better shall redeem it.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: How! all your land sold at a hundreth year's purchase
Cannot repair th'damage of one poor rap,
To thunder at the phrontisterion
Of great Albumazar?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Why man? what harm:

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Sir, you must know my master's heavenly brain
Pregnant with mysteries of metaphysics,
Grows to an embryo of rare contemplation,
Which at full time brought forth, excels by far
The armed fruit of Vulcan's midwifery
That leapt from Jupiter's mighty cranium.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: What of all this?

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Thus one of your bold thunders may abortive
And cause that birth miscarry, that might have proved
An instrument of wonders greater and rarer
Than Apollonius the magician wrought.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Are you your master's countryman?

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Yes: why ask you?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Then must I get an interpreter for your language.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: You need not ▪ with a wind instrument my master made,
In five days you may breathe ten languages
As perfect as the devil, or himself.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: When may I speak with him?

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: When't please the stars.
He pulls you not a hair, nor pares a nail,
Nor stirs a foot without due figuring
The horoscope: sit down a while an't please you,
I see the heavens incline to his approach.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: What's this I pray you?

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: An engine to catch stars,
a maze t'arrest such planets as have lurked
Four thousand years under protection
Of Jupiter and sol.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Pray you speak English.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Sir, 'tis a perspicil, th'best under heaven:
With this I'll read a leaf of that small Iliad
That in a walnut shell was desked, as plainly
Twelve long miles off, as you see Paul's from Highgate.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Wonderful workman of so rare an instrument!

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: 'Twill draw the moon so near that you would swear
The bush of thorns in't prick your eyes: the crystal
Of a large arch multiplies millions,
Work's more than by point blank: and by refractions
Optic and strange, searcheth like th'eye of truth,
All closets that have windows. Have at Rome,
I see the Pope, his Cardinals and his mule,
The English college and the Jesuits,
And what they write and do.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Let me see too.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: So far you can not: for this glass is framed
For eyes of thirty: you are nigh threescore.
But for some fifty miles 'twill serve you,
With help of a refractive glass that's yonder.
For trial sir: where are you now?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: In London.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Ha you found the glass within that chamber?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: What see you?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Wonders, wonders: I see as in a landscape
An honourable throng of noble persons,
As clear as I were under the same roof.
Seems by their gracious brows, and courteous looks
Something they see, which if t b'indifferent
They'll fav'rably accept: if otherwise
They'll pardon, who, or what they be, I know not.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Why that's the coure ▪ at Cambridge forty miles hence, what else?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: A hall thrust full of bareheads, some bald, some bushed,
Some bravely branched.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: That's th'university
Larded with townsmen. Look you there: what now?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Who? I see Dover peer, a man now landing
Attended by two porters that seem to groan
under the burden of two loads of paper.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: That's Coriatus Persicus, and's observations
Of Asia and Afrique.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: The price.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: I dare not sel't.
But here's another of a stranger virtue:
The great Albumazar by wondrous art,
In imitation of this perspicil,
Hath framed an instrument that multiplies
Objects of hearing, as this doth of seeing,
That you may know each whisper from Prester John
Against the wind, as fresh as 'twere delivered
Through a trunk, or Gloucester's listening wall.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: And may I see it sir? bless me once more.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: 'Tis something ceremonious; but you shall try't.
Stand thus. What hear you?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Nothing

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Set your hands thus
That th'vertex of the organ may perpendicularly
Point out our zenith. What hear you now? ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: A humming noise of laughter.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Why that's the court
And university, that now are merry
With an old gentleman in a comedy. What now?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Celestial music, but it seems far off.
List, list, 'tis nearer now.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: 'Tis music twixt the acts. What now?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: And now?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Music again, and strangely delicate.
O most angelical! they sing!

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: And now?
Sing sweetly, that our notes may cause
The heavenly orbs themselves to pause:
And at our music stand as still
As at Jove's amorous will.
So now release them as before,
They've waited long enough, no more.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: 'Tis gone, give me't again. — oh do not so.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: What hear you now?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: No more than a dead oyster.
O let me see this wondrous instrument.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Sir, this is called an otacousticon.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: A cousticon?
Why 'tis a pair of ass's ears, and large ones.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: True: for in such a form the great Albumazar
Hath framed it purposely, as fittest receivers
of sounds, as spectacles like eyes for sight.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: What gold will buy't?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I'll selt you when 'tis finished:
As yet the epiglottis is unperfect.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: 'Soon as you can, and here's ten crowns in earnest.
For when 'tis done, and I have purchased it,
I mean t'entail 't on my heirs male for ever,
Spite of the ruptures of the common law.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Nay rather give't to Flavia for her juncture:
For she that marries you, deserves it richly.

sp.speaker: Cric.
sp.l: Sir, I have spoke with Lelio, and he answers.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Hang Lelio, and his answer's. Come hither Cricca,
Wonder for me, admire, and be astonished,
Marvel thyself to marble at these engines,
These strange Gorgonian instruments.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: At what?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: At this rare perspicil and otacousticon.
For with these two I'll hear and see all secrets,
Undo intelligencers. Pray let my man see
What's done in Rome; his eyes are just as yours are.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Pandolfo, are you mad? be wise and secret:
See you th'steep danger you are tumbling in?
Know you not that these instruments have power
T'unlock the hiddenest closets of whole states?
And you reveal such mysteries to a servant?
Sir be advised, or else you learn no more
Of our unknown philosophy.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Enough.
What news from Lelio? shall I have his sister?

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: He swears and vows he never will consent.
She shall not play with worn antiquities,
Nor lie with snow, and statues; and such replies
That I omit for reverence of your worship.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Not have his sister? Cricca I will have Flavia,
Maugre his head ▪ by means of this astrologer
I'll enjoy Flavia. Are the stars yet inclined
To his divine approach?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: One minute brings him.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: What strologer?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: The learned man I told thee,
Th' high almanac of Germany, an Indian
Far beyond Trebizond and Tripoli,
Close by the world's end: a rare conjurer,
And great astrologer. His name, pray sir?

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Albumazarro meteoroscopico.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: A name of force to hang him without trial.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: As he excels in science, so in title.
He tells of lost plate, horses, and strayed cattle
Directly, as he had stolen them all himself.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Or he, or some of his confederates.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: As thou respects thy life, look to thy tongue,
Albumazar has an otacousticon.
Be silent, reverent, and admire his skill,
See what a promising countenance appears:
Stand still and wonder, wonder and stand still.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Ronca, the bunch of planets new found out
Hanging at th'end of my best perspicil,
Send them to Galileo at Padua;
Let him bestow them where he please. But th'stars
Lately discovered 'twixt the horns of Aries,
Are as a present for Pandolfo's marriage,
And henceforth styled sidera Pandolfaea.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: My marriage Cricca! he foresees my marriage:
Oh most celestial Albumazar!

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: And sends y'a present from the head of Aries.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: My almanac made for th'meridian
And height of Japan, give't th'east Indy company:
There may they smell the price of cloves and pepper,
Monkeys and china-dishes five years ensuing;
and know th'success o'th voyage of Magores.
For in the volume of the firmament
We children of the stars read things to come,
As clearly as poor mortals storeys passed
In speed or Hollingshead.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: The perpetual motion
With a true alarm in't to run twelve hours
Before Mahomet's return.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Deliver it safe
T'a Turkey factor, bid him with care present it
From me to th'house of ottoman.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Pray you stand here, and wonder now for me,
Be astonished at his Gorgon, for I cannot.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Upon my life he proves a mere impostor.
Peace, not a word, be silent and admire.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: As for the issue of th'next summer's wars,
Reveal't to none, keep't to thyself in secret,
As touchstone of my skill in prophesy. Be gone.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: I go sir.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Signior Pandolfo, I pray you pardon me,
Exotic dispatches of great consequence
Stayed me; and casting the nativity
O'th cham of Tartary, and a private conference
With a mercurial intelligence.
You're welcome in a good hour, better minute,
Best second, happiest third, fourth, fifth, and scruple.
Let the twelve houses of the horoscope
Be lodged with fortitudes, and fortunates,
To make you blessed in your designs Pandolfo.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Were't not much trouble to your starry employments,
I a poor mortal would entreat your furtherance
In a terrestrial business.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: My ephemeris lies,
Or I foresee your errant: thus 'tis, thus.
You had a neighbour called Antonio,
A widower like yourself, whose only daughter
Flavia, you love, and he as much admired
Your child Sulpitia. Is not this right?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Yes sir: oh strange! Cricca admire in silence.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: You two decreed a counter-match betwixt you,
And purposed to truck daughters. Is't not so?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Just as you say't. Cricca admire and wonder.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: This no such secret: look to yourself, he'll cheat you.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Antonio after this match concluded,
Having great sums of gold in Barbary,
Desires of you before he consummate
The rites of matrimony, he might go thither,
For three months; but as now 'tis three and three
Since he embarked, and is not yet returned.
Now sir your business is to me, to know
Whether Antonio be dead or living.
I'll tell you instantly.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Hast thou revealed it?
I told it none but thee.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Why stare you?
Are you not well?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I wander 'twixt the poles
And heavenly hinges, amongst excentricals,
Centres, concentrickes, circles, and epicycles,
To hunt out an aspect fit for your business.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Mean ostentation! for shame awake yourself.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: And since the lamp of heaven is newly entered
To cancer, old Antonio is stark dead,
Drowned in the sea stone dead: for radius directorius
In the sixth house; and th'waning moon by Capricorn,
He's dead, he's dead.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: 'Tis an ill time to marry.
The moon grows forked, and walks with Capricorn.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Peace fool: these words are full of mysteries.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: What ominous face, and dismal countenance
Marked for disasters, hated of all the heavens,
Is this that follows you?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: He is my servant,
A plain and honest speaker, but no harm in him.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: What see you in my face?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Horror and darkness, death and gallows,
I de swear th'wertenberg hanged, stoodst thou but two foot higher,
But now thy stars threaten a nearer death.
Sir, send to toll his knell.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: What is he dead?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: He shall be by the dint of many stabs:
Only I spy a little hope of scaping
Through the clouds, and foul aspects of death,

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Sir, pray give no credit to this cheater,
or with his words of art he'll make you dote
As much on his feigned skill, as on fair Flavia.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Stay villain, stay, though safety 't self defends thee
Thou diest.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: Come do thy worst, thrust sure, or die.

sp.speaker: Cric.
sp.l: For heaven's sake gentlemen stay your hands, help, help.
Help Albumazar.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.l: Thus to the hinderer
Of my revenge.

sp.speaker: Cric.
sp.l: Save me Albumazar.

sp.speaker: Furb.
sp.l: And thus, and thus, and thus.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Master I die, I die.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.l: Fliest thou base coward? 'tis not thy heels can save thee.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Oh!

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: What ails thee Cricca?

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: I am dead, I am dead,
Trouble yourself no more.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: What dead and speakst?

sp.speaker: Cric.
sp.l: Only there's left a little breath to tell you.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Why, where art hurt?

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Stabbed with a thousand daggers,
My heart, my lights, my liver, and my skin,
Pierced like a sieve.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Here's not a wound, stand up,
'Tis but thy fear.

sp.speaker: Cric.
sp.l: 'Tis but one wound all over.
Softly, o softly: you've lost the truest servant; farewell I die.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Live by my courtesy, stand up and breath.
The dangerous and malignant influence is past:
But thank my charity that put by the blows,
The least of which threatened a dozen graves.
Now learn to scoff divine astrology,
And slight her servants.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: A chirurgeon, good sir, a surgeon.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Stand up man, thou'st no harm, my life for thine.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Thou'rt well, thou'rt well.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Now I perceive I am:
I pray you pardon me divine astrologer.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I do, but henceforth laugh at astrology
And call her servant's cheaters.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Now to our business: on good Albumazar.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Now since the moon passeth from Capricorn,
Through Aquarius to the watery sign of pisces,
Antonio's drowned, and is devoured by fishes.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Is't certain?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Certain.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Then let my earnestness
Entreat your skill a favour.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: It shall, but first
I'll tell you what you mean to ask me.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Strange!

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Antonio dead that promised you his daughter,
Your business is t'entreat me raise his ghost,
And force it stay at home till't have performed
The promise past, and so return to rest.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: That, that, you've hit it most divine Albumazar.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: 'Tis a hard thing; for de prevatione ad habitum non datur regressus.
O what a business what a master piece
'Tis to raise up his ghost, whose body's eaten
By fish. This work desires a planetary intelligence
Of Jupiter and sol, and these great spirits,
Are proud, fantastical: it asks much charges,
T'entice them from the guiding of their spheres
To wait on mortals.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: So I may have my purpose, spare for no cost.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Sir, spare your purse, we'll do't an easier way.
The work shall cost you nothing.
We have an art is called prestigiatory,
That deals with spirits, and intelligences
Of meaner office and condition,
Whose service craves small charges: with one of these
I'll change some servant, or good friend of yours
To th'perfect shape of this Antonio:
So like in face, behaviour, speech, and action,
That all the town shall swear Antonio lives.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Most necromantical astrologer,
Do this, and take me for your servant ever.
And for your pains, after the transformation
This chain is yours, it cost two hundred pound
Beside the jewel.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: After the work is finished, then — how now?
What lines are these that look sanguineous?
As if the stars conjured to do you mischief?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: How? mean you me?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: They're dusky marks of Saturn.
It seems some stone shall fall upon your head,
Threatening a fracture of the pericranium.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Cricca come hither, fetch me my staff again,
Threescore and ten's returned: a general palsy
Shakes out the love of Flavia with a fear.
Is there no remedy?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Nothing but patience.
The planet threatens so, whose prey you are.
The stars and planets daily war together.
For should they stand at truce but one half hour
This wondrous machine of the world would ruin.
Who can withstand their powerful influence?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: You with your wisdom, good Albumazar.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Indeed th'aegyptian Ptolemy the wise,
Pronounced it as an oracle of truth; sapiens dominabitur astris.
Who's above there? Ronca bring down the cap
Made in the point of Mercury being ascendent:
Here put it on, and in your hand this image,
Framed on a Tuesday when the fierce god of war
Mounted th'horizon in the sign of Aries.
With these walk as unwounded as Achilles,
Dipped by his mother Thetis.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: You bind me to your service.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Next get the man you purpose to transform
And meet me here.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I will not fail to find you.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Meanwhile with scioferical instrument,
By way of azimuth and Almicantarath
I'll seek some happy point in heaven for you.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I rest your servant, sir.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Let all the stars
Guide you with most propitious influence.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Here's a strange man indeed, of skill profound:
How right he knew my business, 'fore he saw me,
and how thou scoff'dst him when we talked in private.
'Tis a brave instrument his otacousticon.

sp.speaker: Cric.
sp.l: In earnest sir I took him for a cheater;
As many, under name of cunning men
With promise of astrology, much abuse
The gaping vulgar, wronging that sacred skill,
That in the stars reads all our actions.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Is there no arches o'er our heads, look Cricca.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: None but the arch of heaven, that cannot fall.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Is not that made of marble? I have read
A stone dropped from the moon: and much I fear
The fit should take her now, and void another.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Fear nothing sir, this charmed mercurial cap
Shields from the fall of mountains: 'tis not a stone
Can check his art, walk boldly.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I do, let's in.

sp.speaker: Trincala.
sp.p: He that saith I am not in love, he lies de cap à poe; for I am idle, choicely neat in my clothes, valiant, and extreme witty: my meditations are loaded with metaphors, and my songs sonnets: not a one shakes his tail, but I sigh out a passion: thus do I to my mistress; but alas I kiss the dog, and she kicks me. I never see a young wanton filly, but, say I, there goes Armellina; nor a lusty strong ass, but I remember myself, and sit down to consider what a goodly race of mules would inherit, if she were willing: only I want utterance, and that's a main mark of love too.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Trincalo. Trincalo.

sp.speaker: Trinc.
sp.p:
O 'tis Armellina: now if she have the wit to begin, as I mean she should, then will I confound her with compliments
drawn from the plays I see at the fortune, and red bull, where I learn all the words I speak and understand not.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Trincalo, what price bear's wheat, and saffron, that your band's so stiff and yellow? not a word? why Trincalo! what business in town? how does all at Totnam? grown mute? What do you bring from the country?

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.p: There 'tis. Now are my floodgates drawn, and I'll surround her. What have I brought sweet bit of beauty? A hundreth thousand salutations o'th' elder house to your most illustrious honour and worship.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: To me these titles? is your basket full of nothing else?

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.p: Full of the fruits of love, most resplendent lady; a present to your worthiness from your worship's poor vassal Trincalo.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: My life on't, he scraped these compliments from his cart, the last load he carried for the progress. What ha' you read that make you grow so eloquent?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Sweet madam, I read nothing but the lines of your ladyship's countenance, and desire only to kiss the skirts of your garment, if you vouchsafe me not the happiness of your white hands.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Come, give's your basket and take it.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: O sweet! now will I never wash my mouth after, nor breath but at my nostrils, lest I lose the taste of her fingers. Armellina, I must tell you a secret if you'll make much on't.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: As it deserves: what is't?

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.p: I love you, dear morsel of modesty, I love: and so truly, that I'll make you mistress of my thoughts, lady of my revenues, and commit all my movables into your hands, that is, I give you an earnest kiss in the high way of matrimony.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Is this the end of all this business?

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.p: This is the end of all business, most beautiful, and most worthy to be most beautiful lady.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.p: Hence fool, hence.

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.p:
Why now she knows my meaning, let it work: she put up the fruit in her lap, and threw away the basket: 'tis a plain sign, she abhors the words, and embraces the meaning: oh lips, no lips, but leaves besmeared with mildew!
O dew no dew, but drops of honey combs! O combs no combs, but fountains full of tears! O tears no tears, but —

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Cricca denies me; no persuasions,
Proffers, rewards, can work him to transform.
Yonder's my country farmer Trincalo.
Never in sitter time good Trincalo.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Like a lean horse t'a fresh and lusty pasture.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: What rent dost pay me for thy farm at Totnam?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Ten pound; and find't too dear a pennyworth.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: My hand here: take it rent-free for three lives,
To serve me in a business I'll employ thee.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Serve you? I'll serve, reserve, conserve, preserve,
Deserve you for th'one half: o Armellina,
A jointure, hai a jointure! what's your employment?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Here's an astrologer has a wondrous secret
To transform men to other shapes, and persons.

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.l: How? transform things to men? I'll bring nine tailors
Refused last muster, shall give five marks a piece
To shape three men of service out of all,
And grant him th'remnant shreds above the bargain.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Now if thou'lt let him change thee, take this lease;
Drawn ready; put what lives thou pleasest.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Stay, sir.
Say I am transformed; who shall enjoy the lease?
I? or the person I must turn to.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Thou,
Thou. The resemblance lasts but one whole day:
Then home true farmer, as thou were't before.

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.l: Where shall poor Trincalo be? how's this? transformed?
Transmuted? how? not I; I love myself
Better than so: there's your lease. I'd not venture
For th'whole fee-simple.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Tell me the difference
Betwixt a fool and wise man.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: I'faith as much
as twixt your worship and myself.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: A wise man
Accepts all fair occasions of advancement,
Flies no commodity for fears of danger,
Ventures and gains, lives easily, drinks good wine,
Fares neatly, is richly clothed, in worthiest company;
While your poor fool and clown, for fear of peril,
Sweats hourly for a dry brown crust to bedward,
And wake's all night for want of moisture.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Well, sir,
I'd rather starve in this my loved image,
Then hazard thus my life, for others looks.
Change is a kind of death, I dare not try it.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: 'Tis not so dangerous as thou takest it; we'll only
Alter thy countenance for a day. Imagine
Thy face masked only: or that thou dreamest all night
Thou were't apparelled in Antonio's form,
And waking findest thyself true Trincalo.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: T'antonio's form? was not Antonio a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Yes, and my neighbour, that's his house.

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.l: O ho!
Now do I smell th'astrologer's trick: he'll steep me
In soldier's blood; or boil me in a cauldron
Of barbarous law French: or anoint me over
With supple oil of great men's services.
For these three means raise yeomen to the gentry.
Pardon me sir: I hate these medicines. Fie!
All my posterity will smell and taste on't
'Long as the house of Trincalo endures.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: There's no such business, thou shall't only seem so
And thus deceive Antonio's family.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Are you assured? 'twould grieve me to be brayed
In a huge mortar, wrought to paste, and moulded
To this Antonio's mould: grant I be turned: what then?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Enter his house, be reverenced by his servants,
And give his daughter Flavia to me in marriage.
The circumstances I'll instruct thee after.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Pray give me leave: this side says do't, this do not.
Before I leave you Tom Trincalo take my counsel.
Thy mistress Armellina is Antonio's maid,
and thou in his shape mayst possess her. Turn.
But if I be Antonio, than Antonio
Enjoys that happiness, not Trincalo.
A pretty trick to make myself a cuckold.
No, no; there, take your lease. I'll hang first. Soft,
Be not so choleric Thomas: if I become Antonio,
Than all his riches follow. This fair occasion
Once vanished, hope not the like; of a stark clown
I shall appear spick and span gentleman.
A pox of ploughs, and carts, and whips, and horses.
Then Armellina shall be given to Trincalo,
Three hundred crowns her portion: we'll get a boy
And call him transformation Trincalo.
I'll do't sir.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Art resolved?

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.l: Resolved? 'tis done ▪
With this condition: after I have given your worship
My daughter Flavia, you shall then move my worship
And much entreat me, to bestow my maid
Upon myself, I should say Trincalo.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Content, and for thy sake will make her portion
Two hundred crowns.

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.l: Now are you much deceived ▪
I never meant it.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: I did but jest.
And yet my hand, I'll do't. For I am mutable
And therefore apt to change. Come, come sir, quickly,
Let's to th'astrologer, and there transform,
Reform, conform, deform me at your pleasure.
I loathe this country countenance; dispatch: my skin
Itches like snakes in April, to be stripped off.
, O quickly, as you love Flavia, quickly.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Signior Pandolfo, y'arrive in happiest hour.
If the seven planets were your nearest kindred,
And all the constellations your allies:
Were the twelve houses, and the inns o'th' zodiac
your own fee-simple; they could ne'er have chosen
A fitter place to favour your designs.
For the great luminaries look from Hilech,
And midst of heaven in angles, conjunctions,
And fortunate aspects of trine and sextile,
Ready to pour propitious influences.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Thank's to your power and curtsy that so placed them.
This is the man that's ready for the business.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Of a most happy countenance, and timber fit
To square to th'gentry: his looks as apt for changing,
As he were covered with chamaeleon's skins.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Except my hands; and 'twill be troublesome
To fit these fingers to Antonio's gloves.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Pray let's about the work as soon as may be.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: First choose a large low room, whose door's full East,
Or near inclining: for th'oriental quarter's
Most bountiful of favours.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I have a parlour
Of a great square and height, as you desire it.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Southward must look a wide and spacious window:
For howsoever Omar, Alchabitius,
Hali, Abenezra, seem something to dissent;
Yet Zoroastres, son of Oromasus,
Hiarcha, Brachman, Thespion gymnesophist,
Gebir, and Budda Babylonicus,
With all the subtle cabalists and Chaldees,
Swear the best influence: for our metamorphosis
Stoops from the South, or as some say, southeast.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: This room's as fit as you had made't of purpose.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Now do I feel the calf of my right leg
Tingle, and dwindle to th'smallness of a bedstaff.
Such a speech more turns my high shoes straight boots.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Ne'er were those authors cited to better purpose.
For through that window all Pandolfo's treasures
Must take their flight and fall upon my shoulders.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Now if this light meridional had a large casement
That overlooked some unfrequented alley,
'Twere much more proper: for th'intelligences
are nice and coy, scorning to mix their essence
With thronged disturbance of cross multitudes.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Spoken by art ▪ Albumazar: a provident setter:
For so shall we receive what thou handest out
Free from discovery. But in my conscience
All windows point full South for such a business.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Go to my house, satisfy your curious choice,
But credit me, this parler's fit, it neighbours
To a blind alley, that in busiest termtime
Feels not the footing of one passenger.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Now then declining from theourgia,
Artenosoria, pharmacia, rejecting
Necro-puro-geo-hydro-cheiro-coscinomancy,
With other vain and superstitious sciences,
We'll anchor at the art prestigiatory,
That represents one figure for another,
With smooth deceit abusing th'eyes of mortals.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: O my right arm! 'tis altered, and methinks
Longs for a sword: these words have slain a ploughman.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: And since the moon's the only planet changing:
For from the Neomenia in seven days
To the Dicotima, in seven more to th'pauselinum,
And in as much from plenilunium
Thorough Dicotima to Neomenia,
'Tis she must help us in this operation.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: What towns are these? the strangeness of these names,
Hath scaled the marks of many a painful harvest,
And made my new-piled fingers itch for dice.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Deeply considered wondrous Albumazar:
Oh let me kiss those lips that flow with science.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: For by her various looks she intimates
To understanding souls, that only she
Hath power t'effect a true formation.
'Cause then your parlour to be swept carefully,
Washed, rubbed, perfumed, hanged round from top to bottom
With pure white lunary tapestry, or needlework;
But if 'twere cloth of silver, 'twere much better.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Good, good! A rich beginning: good! what's next?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Spread all the floor with finest holland sheets,
And over them fair damask tablecloths,
Above all these draw me chaste virgin's aprons:
The room, the work, and workman must be pure.

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.l: With virgin's aprons? th'whole compass of this city
Can not afford a dozen.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: So, there's shirts
And bands to furnish all on's for a twelvemonth.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: An altar in the midst, loaded with plate
Of silver, basins, ewers, cups, candlesticks,
Flagons and beakers, salts, chargers, casting-bottles.
'Twere not amiss to mix some bowls of gold,
So they be massy; the better to resemble
The lovely brotherhood of sol and luna.
Also some diamonds for Jupiter.
For by the whiteness and bright sparkling lustres
We allure th'intelligences to descend.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Furbo and I are those intelligences
That must attend upon the magistery.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Now for the ceremonious sacrifice,
Provide such creatures as the moon delights in,
Two sucking lambs, white as the Alpine snow:
Yet if they have a mole or two, 'twill pass.
The moon herself wants not her spots.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: 'Tis true.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Were they hell-black, we'd make a shift to eat them.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: White capons, pheasants, pigeons: one little blackbird
Would stain and spoil the work. Get several wines
To quench the holy embers: Rhenish, Greek wine,
White muskadel, sherry, and rich canary,
So't be not grown too yellow: for the quicker,
Brisker, and older, the better for these ceremonies.
The more abundance, sooner shall we finish.
For 'tis our rule in such like businesses,
Who spares most, spends most: either this day must do't,
Or th'revolution of five hundred years
Cannot: so fit are all the heavens to help us.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: A thousand thanks, thou'lt make a complete cheat.
Thus loaded with this treasure, cheered with wine,
Strengthened with meat: we'll carry thee in triumph,
As the great general of our achievement.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Sir, for rich plate and jewels I have store,
But know not how to furnish you with hangings.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Cannot you borrow from the shops? four hours
Shall render all as fair as you received it.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: That can I easily do.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: And hear you sir:
If you chance meet with boxes of white comfits,
Marchpane, dry sucket, macaroons and diet-bread,
'Twill help on well.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: To furnish out our banquet.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I had clean forgotten, we must have amber Greece,
The greyest can be found, some dozen ounces,
I'll use but half a dram: but 'tis our fashion
T'offer a little from a greater lump.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: All shall be done with expedition.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: And when your man's transformed, the chain you promised.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: My hand: my deeds shall wait upon my promise.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Lead then with happy foot to view the chamber.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I go sir. Trincalo attend us here,
And not a word on peril of thy life.

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.l: Sir, if they kill me I'll not stir a foot,
And if my tongue's pulled out, not speak a word.

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.l: O what a business 'tis to be transformed!
My master talks of four and twenty hours,
But if I move these flags of yeomanry,
Guild in the sear, and shine in bloom of gentry,
'Tis not their astrology, nor sacrifice,
Shall force me cast that coat. I'll never part with't
Till I be sheriff of th'county, and in commission
Of peace and quorum. Then will I get m'a clerk,
A practised fellow, wiser than my worship.
And domineer amongst my fearful neighbours,
And feast them bountifully with their own bribes.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Trincalo!

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Wear a gold chain at every quarter sessions,
Look big, and grave, and speak not one wise word.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Trincalo!

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Examine wenches got with child, and curiously
Search all the circumstances: have blank mittimuses
Printed in readiness; breathe naught but sirrah,
Rogue, ha? how? hum? Constable look to your charge.
Then vouch a statute and a Latin sentence,
Wide from the matter.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Trincalo.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Licence all alehouses,
Match my son transformation t'a knight's daughter,
And buy a bouncing pedigree of a Welsh herald: and then —

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: What in such serious meditations?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Faith no; but building castles in the air.
While th'weather's fit: oh Cricca, such a business!

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: What is't?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Nay soft, they're secrets of my master.
Locked in my breast: he has the key at's purse-strings.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: My master's secret? keep it good farmer, keep it,
I would not lend an ear to't if thou'dst hire me. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: O how it boils and swells: if I keep't longer,
'Twill grow t'impostume in my breast, and choke me, Cricca.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Adieu good Trincalo, the secrets of our betters
Are dangerous, I dare not know't.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: But hearest thou,
Say I should tell, canst keep't as close as I do?

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Yes: but I had rather want it. Adieu.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Albumazar.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Albumazar.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Prithee.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Albumazar
Th'astrologer hath undertaken to change me
T'antonio's shape: this done, must I give Flavia
To my old master, and his maid to Trincalo.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: But where's Pandolfo and Albumazar?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Gone newly home to choose a chamber fitting
For transmutation: so now my heart's at ease.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: I fear the skill and cunning of Albumazar
With his black art, by whom Pandolfo seeks
To compass Flavia, spite of her brother Lelio,
And his own son Eugenio that loves her dear.
I'll lose no time, but find them and reveal
the plot and work to cross this accident.
But Trincalo, art thou so rash and venturous
To be transformed with hazard of thy life?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: What care I for a life, that have a lease
For three? But I am certain there's no danger in't.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: No danger? cut thy finger and that pains thee;
Then what wil't do to shred and mince thy carcase,
Bury't in horse-dung, mould it new, and turn it
T'antonio? and when thou'rt changed, if Lelio
Smell out your plot, what worlds of punishment
Thou must endure, poor Trincalo! The desire
Of gains abuses thee: be not transformed.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Cricca thou understandest not: for Antonio
Whom I resemble, suffers all: not I.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Yonder they come, I'll hence and haste to Lelio.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: The chamber's fit: provide the plate and hangings,
And other necessaries: give strict order
The room be cleansed, perfumed, and hanged, meanwhile ,
With astrolabe, and meteoroscope,
I'll find the cusp and Alfriduria,
And know what planet is in Cazimi.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: All shall be ready sir, as you command it.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Doctor Albumazar, I have a vein of drinking,
And artery of lechery ▪ runs through my body:
Pray when you turn me gentleman, preserve
Those two, if 't may be done with reputation.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Fear not, I'll only call the first, good fellowship,
And th'other, civil recreation.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: And when you come to th'heart', spoil not the love of Armellina.
And in my brain leave as much discretion
As may spy falsehood in a tavern reckoning;
And let me alone for bounty to wink and pay't.
And if you change me perfectly,
I'll bring y'a dozen knights for customers.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I warrant thee: sir are you well instructed
In all these necessaries?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: They're in my table-book.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Forget not clothes for th'new transformed, and robes
For me to sacrifice: you know the fashion.
I'll rather change five, than apparel one:
For men have living souls, clothes are unanimate.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Here take this ring, deliver it to my brother,
An officer in the wardrobe, he'll furnish you
With robes and clothes of any stuff, or fashion.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Almuten Alchochoden of the stars attend you.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I kiss your hands divine astrologer.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Up quickly Trincalo to my child Sulpitia,
Bid her lay out my fairest damask tablecloths.
The fairest holland sheets, all th'silver plate,
Two gossips cups of gold: my greatest diamonds:
Make haste.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: As fast as Alchochoden and Almuten
Can carry me: for sure these two are devils.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: This is that blessed day I so much longed for:
Four hours attendance till my man be changed,
Fast locks me in the lovely arms of Flavia. Away Trincalo.
How slow the day slides on! When we desire
Times hast, it seems to lose a match with lobsters,
And when we wish him stay, he imps his wings
With feathers plumed with thought. Why Trincalo!

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Come let's away for cloth of silver,
Wine and materials for the sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Eugenio, these are wonders passed belief.
Is your old father of so poor a judgement
To think it in the power of man to turn
One person to another?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Lelio, his desire
T'enjoy your sister Flavia, begets hope,
Which like a waking dream, makes false appearance
Lively as truth itself.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: But who's the man
That works these miracles?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: An astrologer.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: How deals astrology with transmutation?

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Under the veil and colour of astrology,
He clouds his hellish skill in necromancy.
Believe it, by some art, or false imposture,
He'll much disturb your love, and yours, Eugenio.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Eugenio, 'tis high time for us t'awake.
And as you love our Flavia, and I
Your sister fair Sulpitia; let's do something
Worthy their beauties. Who falls into a sea,
Swollen big with tempest, but he boldly beats
The waves with arms and legs, to save his life?
So let us strive 'gainst troublous storms of love,
With our best power, lest after we ascribe
The loss to our dull negligence, not fortune.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Lelio, had I no interest in your sister,
The holy league of friendship should command me,
Besides the seconding Sulpitia's love,
Who to your nobleness commends her life.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: She cannot out-love me, nor you out-friend me,
For th'sacred name whereof, I have rejected
Your father's offers, importunities,
Letters, conditions, servants, friends, and lastly
His tender of Sulpitia in exchange
For Flavia ▪ but though I love your sister
Like mine own soul; yet did the laws of friendship
Master that strong affection; and denied him.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Thanks ever, and as long shall my best service
Wait on your will. Cricca our hope's in thee,
Thou must instruct us:

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: You must trust in fortune
That make's or marr's the wisest purposes.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: What sayest? What thinkst?

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Here's no great need of thinking
Not speech; the oil of scorpions cures their poison.
The thing itself that's bent to hurt and hinder you
Offers a remedy: 'tis no sooner known
But th'worst on't is prevented.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: How good Cricca?

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Soon as you see this false Antonio
Come near your doors with speeches made of purpose,
Full of humility and compassion:
With long narrations how he 'scaped from shipwreck
And other feigned inventions of his dangers:
Bid him be gone; and if he press to enter,
Fear not the reverence of your father's looks,
Cudgel him thence.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: But were't not better Cricca
Keep him fast locked, till his own shape return,
And so by open course of law correct him?

sp.speaker: Cric.
sp.l: No. For my master would conceive that counsel
Sprung from my brains: and so should I repent it.
Advise no more, but home and charge your people,
That if Antonio come, they drive him thence
With threatening words, and blows if need be.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: 'Tis done.
I kiss your hands Eugenio.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Your servant, sir.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Cricca commend my service to my mistress.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Commend it t'her yourself. Marked you not, while
We talked ▪ how through the window she attended,
And fed her eyes on you? there she's.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: 'Tis true.
And as from nights of storms the glorious sun
Breaks from the East, and chaseth thence the clouds
That choked the air with horror; so her beauty
Dispels sad darkness from my troubled thoughts,
And clears my heart.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Life of my soul well met.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: How is't my dearest Flavia?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Eugenio,
As best becomes a woman, most unfortunate.
That having loved so long, and been persuaded
Her chaste affection was by yours requited,
Have by delays been famished. Had I concealed
Those flames your virtue kindled, than y'had sued,
Entreated, sworn, and vowed, and long ere this
Wrought all means possible to effect our marriage.
But now.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Sweet soul despair not, weep not thus,
Unless you wish my heart should lifeblood drop,
Fast as your eyes do tears. What is't you fear?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: First that you love me not.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Not love my Flavia?
Wrong not your judgement: rip up this amorous breast
And in that temple see a heart that burns
I'th' vestal sacrifice of chastest love,
Before your beauty's deity.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: If so,
Whence grows this coldness in soliciting
My brother to the match?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Consider sweetest,
I have a father rival in my love;
And though no duty, reverence, nor respect
Have power to change my thoughts: yet 'tis not comely
With open violence to withstand his will;
But by fair courses try to divert his mind
From disproportioned affections.
And if I cannot, than nor fear of anger,
Nor life, nor lands, shall cross our purposes.
Comfort yourself sweet Flavia: for your brother
Seconds our hopes with his best services.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: But other fears oppress me: methinks I see
Aontonio my old father, new returned,
Whom all intelligence gave drowned this three months,
Enforcing me to marry th'fool Pandolfo,
Thus to obtain Sulpitia for himself.
And so last night I dreamed, and ever since
Have been so scared, that if you haste not
Expect my death.

sp.speaker: Eug
sp.l: Dreams flow from thoughts of things we most desire,
Or fear, and seldom prove true prophets, would they did.
Then were I now in full possession
Of my best Flavia: as I hope I shall be.

sp.speaker: Cric.
sp.l: Sir, pray take your leave, this to no end,
'T will but increase your grief and hers.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Farewell
Sweet Flavia, rest contented with assurance
Of my best love and service.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Farewell Eugenio.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Flavia I kiss your hands.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Sulpitia I pray you pardon me, I saw you not.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p: i'faith you have some fixed thoughts draw your eyes inward when you see not your friends before you.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: True, and I think the same that trouble you.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p: Then 'tis the love of a young gentleman, and bitter hatred of an old dotard.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: 'Tis so, witness your brother Eugenio, and the rotten carcase of Pandolfo. Had I a hundred hearts, I should want room to entertain his love, and the other's hate.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p: I could say as much, were't not sin to slander the dead. Miserable wenches, how have we offended our fathers, that they should make us the price of their dotage, the medicine of their griefs, that have more need of physic ourselves? I must be frost-bitten with the cold of your dad's winter, that mine may thaw his old ice with the spring of your sixteen. I thank my dead mother that left me a woman's will in her last testament: that's all the weapons we poor girls can use, and with that will I fight 'gainst father, friends, and kindred, and either enjoy Lelio, or die in the field in's quarrel.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Sulpitia, you are happy that can withstand your fortune with so merry a resolution.

sp.speaker: Su.
sp.p: Why? should I twine mine arms to cables, and sigh my soul to air? Sit up all night like a watching candle, and distil my brains through my eyelids? your brother loves me, and I love your brother; and where these two consent, I would fain see a third could hinder us.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Alas, our sex is most wretched, nursed up from infancy in continual slavery. No sooner able to pray for ourselves, but they brayle and hud us so with sour awe of parents, that we dare not offer to bate at our own desires. And whereas it becomes men to vent their amorous passions at their pleasure; we poor souls must rake up our affections in the ashes of a burned heart, not daring to sigh, without excuse of the spleen, or fit of the mother.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: I plainly will profess my love of Lelio, 'tis honest, chaste, and stains not modesty. Shall I be married to Antonio, that hath been a soused sea-fish, this three months? and if he be alive comes home with as many impairs, as a hunting gelding fallen packhorse. No, no, I'll see him freeze to crystal first. In other things, good father, I am your most obedient daughter, but in this a pure woman. 'tis your part to offer, mine to refuse if I like not. Lelio's a handsome gentleman, young, fresh, rich, and well-fashioned, and him will Sulpitia have, or die a maid: and i'faith the temper of my blood tells me I was never born to so cold a misfortune. Fie Flavia, fie wench, no more with tears and sighs, cheer up, Eugenio to my knowledge loves you, and you shall have him: I say you shall have him.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: I doubt not of his love, but know no means, how he dares work against so great a rival: your father in a spleen may disinherit him.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: And give't to whom? has none but him and me: what though he dote a while upon your beauty; he will not prove unnatural to his son. Go to your chamber: my genius whispers in my ear, and swears this night we shall enjoy our loves, and with that hope farewell.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Farewell Sulpitia.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: While the astrologer hews out Trincalo,
Squaring and framing him t'antonio,
Cricca I'll make thee partner of a thought
that some thing troubles me.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Say, sir, what is't?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I have no heart to give Albumazar
The chain I promised him.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Deliver it me
And I'll present it to him in your name.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: 'Thas been an heirloom to our house four hundreth years,
And should I leave it now, I fear good fortune
Would sly from us, and follow it.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Then give him
The price in gold.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: It comes to a hundred pounds.
And how would that well husbanded grow in time?
I was a fool to promise, I confess it,
I was too hot and forward in the business.

sp.speaker: Cric.
sp.l: Indeed I wondered that your wary thriftiness
Not wont to drop one penny in a quarter
Idly, would part with such a sum so easily.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: My covetous thrift aims at no other mark
Then in fit time and place to show my bounty.
Who gives continually, may want at length
Wherewith to feed his liberality.
But for the love of my dear Flavia
I would not spare my life, much less my treasure.
Yet if with honour I can win her cheaper,
Why should I cast away so great sum?

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: True: I have a trick now hatching in my brain
How you may handsomely preserve your credit,
And save the chain.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I would gladly do it,
But fear he understands us what we say.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: What can you lose to try't, if it take
There's so much saved, if otherwise, nothing lost.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: What is't good Cricca?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Soon as Albumazar comes, loaded with news
Of th'transmutation of your servant Trincalo,
I'll entertain him here: meanwhile steal you
Closely into the room, and quickly hide
Some special piece of plate: then run out amazed,
Roaring, that all the street may know you're robbed.
Next threaten-to attach him and accuse him
Before a justice, and in th'end agree,
If he restore the plate, you'll give the chain,
otherwise not.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: But if we be discovered!
For by his instruments and familiars
He can do much.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Lay all the fault on Trincalo.
But here's the main point. If you can dissemble
Cunningly, and frame your countenance to express
Pity and anger, that so learned a man
Should use his friend so basely: if you can call
An outcry well, roar high, and terrible ▪

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I'll fetch a cry from th'bottom of my heels
But I'll roar loud enough; and thou must second me
With wonder at the sudden accident.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: But yours is the main part, for as you play't
You win or lose the chain.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: No more, no more, he comes.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Signior Pandolfo, three quarters of an hour
Renders your servant perfectly transformed.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Is he not wholly changed? what parts are wanting?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Antonio's shape hath clothed his bulk and visage,
Only his hands and feet, so large and callous,
Require more time to supple.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Pray you sir
How long shall he retain this metamorphosis?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: The complete circle of a natural day.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: A natural day? Are any days unnatural?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I mean the revolution o'th' first mover,
Just twice twelve hours, in which period the rapt motion thieves, thieves!
Rolls all the orbs from East to occident.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Help, help, thieves, thieves, neighbours I am robbed,

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: What a noise make you sir?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Have I not reason
That thus am robbed, thieves, thieves, call constables,
The watch, and sergeants. Friends and constables,
Neighbours I am undone.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: This well begun
So he hold out still with a higher strain.
What ails you sir?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Cricca my chamber's spoilt
of all my hangings, clothes, and silver plate.

sp.speaker: Cric.
sp.l: Why this is bravely feigned; continue sir.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Lay all the goldsmiths, keepers, marshals, bailiffs.

sp.speaker: Cric.
sp.l: Fie sir, your passion falls, cry louder, roar
That all the street may hear.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Thieves, thieves, thieves!
All that I had is gone, and more than all.

sp.speaker: Cric.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha: hold out, hold out; lay out a lion's throat,
A little louder.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I can cry no longer,
My throat's sore, I am robbed, I am robbed, all's gone.
Both my own treasure, and the things I borrowed.
Make thou an outcry, I have lost my voice:
Cry fire, and then they'll hear thee.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Good, good, thieves,
What ha' you lost?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Wine, jewels, tablecloths,
A cupboard of rich plate.

sp.speaker: Cric.
sp.l: Fie, you'll spoil all.
Now you outdo it. Say but a bowl or two.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Villain, I say all's gone; the room's as clean
As a wip't looking-glass: oi me, oi me.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: What, in good earnest?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Fool in accursed earnest.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: You gull me sure.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: The window towards the South stand's open, from whence
Went all my treasure. Where's th'astrologer?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Here sir: and hardly can abstain from laughing
To see you vex yourself in vain.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: In vain Albumazar?
I left my plate with you, and 'tis all vanished,
And you shall answer it.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: O! were it possible
By power of art, to check what art hath done,
Your man should ne'er be changed: to wrong me thus
With foul suspicion of flat felony?
Your plate, your cloth of silver, wine, and jewels,
Linen, and all the rest, I gave to Trincalo,
And for more safety, locked them in the lobby.
He'll keep them carefully. But as you love your mistress
Disturb him not this half hour, lest you'll have him
Like to a centaur, half clown, half gentleman.
Suffer his foot and hand that's yet untouched,
To be ennobled like his other members.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Albumazar, I pray you pardon me,
Th'unlooked-for bareness of the room amazed me.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: How? think you me so negligent to commit
So rich a mass of treasure to th'open danger
Of a large casement, and suspicious alley?
No sir, my sacrifice no sooner done
But I wrapped all up safe, and gave it Trincalo.
I could be angry, but that your sudden fear
Excuses you. Fie, such a noise as this
Half an hour past, had scared th'intelligences,
And spoiled the work, but no harm done: go walk
Westward, directly westward, one half hour:
Then turn back, and take your servant turned t'antonio.
And as you like my skill perform your promise.
I mean the chain.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Content. Let's still go westward,
Westward good Cricca, still directly westward.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Harpax. Furbo, and Ronca, come out, all's clear,
Why here's a noble prize worth venturing for.
Is not this braver than sneak all night in danger,
Picking of locks, or hooking clothes at windows?
Here's plate, and gold, and cloth, and meat and wine,
All rich: and easily got. Ronca stay here about,
And wait till Trincalo come forth: then call him
With a low reverence Antonio,
Give him this gold with thanks, tell him he lent it
Before he went to Barbary.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: How lose ten pieces?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: There's a necessity in't, devise some course
To get't again: if not; our gain's sufficient
To bear that loss. Furbo find out Bavilona
The courtesan, let her feign herself a gentlewoman
Enamoured of Antonio, bid her invite him
To banquet with her, and by all means possible
Force him stay there two hours.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Why two hours?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: That in that time thou mayst convey
our treasure to the inn, and speak a boat
Ready for Gravesend, and provide a supper:
Where, with those precious liquours, and good meats,
We'll cheer ourselves; and thus well fed, and merry,
Take boat by night.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: And what will you do?

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: First in and usher out our changeling Trincalo:
Then finish up a business of great profit,
Begun with a rich merchant, that admires
My skill in alchemy. I must not lose it.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Harpax bestow the plate, Furbo our beards,
Black patches for our eyes, and other properties,
And at the time and place meet all at supper.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Stand forth transformed Antonio fully mewed
From brown sore feathers of dull yeomanry
To th'glorious bloom of gentry; prune yourself slick,
Swear boldly you're the man you represent
To all that dare deny't.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: I find my thoughts
Most strangely altered ▪ but methinks my face
Feels still like Trincalo.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: You imagine so.
Senses are oft deceived. As an attentive angler
Fixing his steady eyes on the swift streams
Of a steep tumbling torrent, no sooner turns
His sight to land, but giddy, thinks the firm banks
And constant trees, move like the running waters:
So you that thirty years have lived in Trincalo,
Changed suddenly, think you're so still; but instantly
These thoughts will vanish.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Give me a lookingglass ▪
To read your skill in these new lineaments.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: I'd rather give you poison: for a glass
By secret power of cross reflections,
And optic virtue, spoils the wondrous work
Of transformation, and in a moment turns you ▪
spite of my skill, to Trincalo, as before.
We read that Apuleius by a rose
Changed from an ass to man: so by a mirror,
You'll lose this noble lustre, and turn ass.
I humbly take my leave; but still remember
T'avoid the devil and a looking glass.
Newborn Antonio, I kiss your hands.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Divine Albumazar I kiss your hands.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Now am I grown a gentleman, and a fine one,
I know't by th'kissing of my hands so courtly,
My courteous knees bend in so true a distance,
As if my foot walked in a frame of purpose.
Thus I accost you: or thus, sweet sir, your servant:
Nay more, your servant's servant: that's your grand-servant.
I could descend from th'top of Paul's to th'bottom,
And on each step strew parting compliments,
Strive for a door while a good carpenter
Might make a new one. I am your shadow sir,
And bound to wait upon you. I'faith I will not: pray sir, etc.
O brave Albumazar!

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Just Aesop's crow, prinked up in borrowed feathers.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: My veins are filled with newness: o for a chirurgeon
To open this arm, and view my gentle blood,
To try if't run two thousand pounds a year.
I feel my understanding is enlarged
With the rare knowledge of this latter age.
A sacred fury oversways me. Prime!
Deal quickly ▪ play, discard, I set ten shillings six pence.
You see't? my rest, five and fifty. Boy, more cards;
And as thou goest, lay out some roaring oaths
For me; I'll pay thee again with interest.
O brave Albumazar!

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: How his imagination boils, and works in all things
He ever saw or heard!

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: At gleek? content.
A mournival of ases, gleek of knaves,
Just nine apiece. Sir my grey Barbary
'Gainst your dun cow, three train scents and th'course,
For fifty pound: as I am a gentleman
I'll meet next cocking, and bring a haggard with me
That stoops as free as lightning, strikes like thunder.
I lie? my reputation you shall hear on't.
O brave Albumazar!

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: He'll grow stark mad I fear me.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Now I know
I am perfectly transformed, my mind incites me
To challenge some brave fellow for my credit,
And for more safety, get some friend in private
To take the business up in peace and quiet.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Signior Antonio?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: There's not a crumb of Trincalo.
In all this frame, but th'love of Armellina:
Were't not for thee I'd travail, and home again
As wise as I went over.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Signior Antonio? welcome ten thousand times:
Blessed be the heavens and seas for your return.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: I thank you sir: Antonio is your servant,
I am glad to see you well. Fie, I kiss your hands: and thus accost you.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: This three months all your kindred, friends and children,
Mourned for your death.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: And so they well might do,
For five days I was under water; and at length
Got up and spread myself upon a chest,
Rowing with arms, and steering with my feet;
And thus in five days more got land: believe it
I made a most incredible escape,
And safe return from Barbary: at your service.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Welcome ten thousand times from Barbary.
No friend more glad to see Antonio
Then I: nor am I thus for hope of gain;
But that I find occasion to be grateful
By your return. Do you remember sir,
Before you went, as I was once arrested,
and could not put in bail; you passing by,
Lent me ten pound, and so discharged the debt?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Yes, yes, as well as 'twere but yesterday.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Oft have I waited at your house with money,
And many thanks: but you were still beyond seas.
Now am I happy of this fair occasion
To testify my honest care to pay you:
For you may need it.

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.l: Sir, I do indeed,
Witness my treasure cast away by shipwreck.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Is the gold good, for mine was good I lent you.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: It was, and so is this. Signior Antonio, for this courtesy
Call me your servant.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Farewell good servant, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha. I know not so much as his name! ten pound? this change is better than my birth: for in all the years of my yeomanry I could never yoke two crowns, and now I have herded ten fair twenty shilling pieces. Now will I go to this astrologer, and hire him turn my cart to a caroche, my four jades to two pair of Dutch mares, my mistress Armellina to a lady, my plowboy Dick to two guarded footmen: then will I hurry myself to the mercer's books, wear rich clothes, be called Tony by a great man, sell my lands, pay no debts, hate citizens, and beat sergeants: and when all fails, sneak out of Antonio with a twopenny lookingglass, and turn as true Trincalo as ever.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Signior Antonio, welcome.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: My life here's ten pound more. I thank you heartily.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.l: Never in fitter season could I find you.
If you remember sir, before you went
To Barbary, I lent you ten pound in gold.

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.l: Faith I remember no such thing excuse me.
What may I call your name?

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.l: My name is Harpax,
Your friend and neighbour, of your old acquaintance,

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.l: What Harpax! I am your servant, I kiss your hands:
you must excuse me, you never lent me money.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Sir, as I live, ten twenty-shilling pieces.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Dangers at sea, I find, have hurt my memory.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Why here's your own hand-writing sealed and signed,
In presence of your cousin Julio.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: 'Tis true, 'tis true; but I sustained great losses
By reason of the shipwreck. Here's five pieces,
Will that content you? and tomorrow morning
Come to my house and take the rest.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Well sir,
Though my necessity would importune you
For all, yet on your worship's word, the rest
I'll call for in the morning. Farewell Antonio.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: I see we gentlemen can sometime borrow
As well as lend, and are as loath to pay
As meaner men. I'll home, lest other creditors
Call for the rest.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Signior Antonio? I saw you as you landed,
And in great haste followed to congratulate
Your safe return, with these most wish't embraces.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: And I accept your joy with like affection.
How do you call yourself?

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Have you forgotten
Your dear friend Ronca, whom you loved so well?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: O I remember now my dear friend Ronca.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Thanks to the fortune of the seas that saved you.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: I fear I owe him money: how shall I shift him?
How does your body Ronca?

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: My dear Antonio,
Never so well as now I have the power
Thus to embrace my friend, whom all th'exchange
Gave drowned for three whole months. My dear Antonio.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I thank you.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: While my dear Ronca
Clipped me, my purse shook dangerously; yet both his arms
And hands embraced my neck: here's none behind me,
how can this be?

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Most dear Antonio,
Was not your passage dangerous from Barbary?
We had great winds and tempests; and I fear me,
You felt the force at sea.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Yes dearest Ronca.
How's this? I see his hands, and yet my purse is gone.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Signior Antonio, I see your mind's much troubled
About affairs of worth; I take my leave,
And kiss your hands of liberality.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: And kiss my hands of liberality?
I gave him nothing: oh my purse, my purse!
Dear master Ronca.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: What's your pleasure sir?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Show me your hand.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Here 'tis.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: But where's th'other?

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Why here.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: But I mean where's your other hand?

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Think you me the giant with a hundred hands?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Give me your right.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: My right?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Your left.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: My left?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Now both.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: There's both my dear Antonio ▪
Keep yourself dark, eat broth; your fearful passage,
And want of natural rest hath made you frantic.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Villain, rogue, cutpurse, thief, dear Ronca stay: he's gone
I'th devil's name, how could this fellow do it?
I felt his hands fast locked about my neck;
And still he spoke, it could not be his 〈◊〉
For that was full of dear Antonio.
My life he stol't with's feet: such a trick more
Will work worse with me then a lookingglass.
To lose five pound in curtsy, and the rest
In salutation!

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Signior Antonio,
What ails you?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Ronca a rogue, a cutpurse,
Hath robbed me of five twenty-shilling pieces.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: What kind of man was he? something like me?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Had such a thievish countenance as your own,
But that he wore a black patch o'er his eye.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Met you with Ronca? 'tis the cunningest nimmer
Of the whole company of cutpurse hall ▪
I am sorry I was not here to warn you of him.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.l: Furbo no more, unless thy words were charms
Of power to revive him: antonio's dead.
He's dead, and in his death hath buried
All my delights: my ears are deaf to music
That sounds of pleasure: sing then the doleful'st notes
That ere were set by melancholy: oh Antonio!
Flow streams of liquid salt from my sad eyes,
To celebrate his mournful exequies.
Antonio's dead, he's dead, and I remain
To draw my poor life in continual pain,
Till it have paid to his sad memory
Duty of love: o then most willingly
Drowned with my tears, as he with waves, I die.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.l: Break thy sad strings, and instrument: oh strange! he's here.
Signior Antonio! my heart's sweet content!
My life and better portion of my soul!
Are you returned? and safe? for whose sad death
I spent such streams of tears, and gusts of sighs?
Or is't my love, that to my longing fancy
Frames your desired shape, and mocks my senses?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Whom do you talk withal fair gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.l: With my best friend, commander of my life,
My most beloved Antonio.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: With me?
What's your desire with me sweet lady?

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.l: Sir to command me, as you have done ever,
To what you please: for all my liberty
Lies in your service.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Now I smell the business ▪
This is some gentlewoman enamoured
With him whose shape I bear: fie, what an ass
Was I to strange myself, and lose th'occasion
Of a good banquet, and her company?
I'll mend it as I can. Madam I did but jest
to try if absence caused you to forget
A friend that loved you ever.

sp.speaker: Bev.
sp.l: Forget Antonio,
Whose dear remembrance doth inform the soul
Of your poor servant Bevilona? no,
No, had you died, it had not quenched one spark
Of th'sweet affection which your love hath kindled
In this warm breast.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Madam, the waves had drowned me.
