But that your love held up my chin.

sp.speaker: Bev.
sp.l: Wil't please you
Enter, and rest yourself, refresh the weariness
Of your hard travel: I have good wine and fruits,
My husband's out of town: you shall command
My house, and all that's in't.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Why are you married?

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.l: Have you forgotten my husband? an angry roarer?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: O I remember him: but if he come?

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.l: Whence grows this fear? how come you so respectful?
You were not wont be numbed with such a coldness.
Go in sweet life, go in.

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.l: O! I remember while I lived in Barbary
A pretty song the Moors sing to a gridiron:
Sweet madam by your favour I'll sing't to this.
Alcoch dolash, etc. thus 'tis in English.
My heart in flames doth fry
Of thy beauty,
While I
Die.
Fie?
And why
Shouldst thou deny
Me thy sweet company?
My brains to tears do flow
While all below
Doth glow.
O!
Foe
If so,
How canst thou go
About to say me no?
This the Moors call two wings upon a gridiron.
But it goes sweeter far 'Oth' iron instrument.

sp.speaker: Bev.
sp.l: There's one within my kitchen ready strung: go in.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Sweet lady pardon me, I'll follow you.
Happy Antonio in so rare a mistress!
But happier I, that in his place enjoy her:
I say still, there's no pleasure like transforming.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Now is the ass expecting of a banquet,
Ready to court, embrace, and kiss his mistress.
But I'll soon stave him. Tick, tock, what ho!

sp.speaker: Bev.
sp.l: Who's that so boldly knocks? I am not within;
Or busy: why so importunate? who is't?

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: 'Tis I.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.l: Your name?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Thomas up William, up Morgan, up Davie, up Roger, etc.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Spinola's camp's broke loose: a troop of soldiers!

sp.speaker: Bev.
sp.l: Oi me! my husband! Oi me wretch, 'tis my husband.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: One man, and wear so many names!

sp.speaker: Bev.
sp.l: O sir,
'Has more outrageous devils in his rage,
Than names. As you respect your life, avoid him.
Down at that window.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: 'Tis as high as Paul's.
Open the garden door.

sp.speaker: Bev.
sp.l: He 'Has the keys.
Down at some window, as you love your life,
Tender my honour, and your safety.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Bevilona?
Down, or I'll break the doors, and with the splinters
Beat all thy bones to pieces: down you whore!

sp.speaker: Bev.
sp.l: Be patient but a little; I come instantly.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Ha'you no trunk nor chest to hide me?

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.l: None sir.
Alas I am clean undone, it is my husband.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Doubtless, this whore hath some of her companions
That wrong me thus. But if I catch the villain,
I'll bathe my hungry sword, and sharp revenge,
In his heartblood. Come down.

sp.speaker: Bev.
sp.l: I cannot stay.
There stands an empty hogshead with a false bottom
to open and shut at pleasure: come hither, in,
In, as you love your life.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: But hear you madam,
Is there no lookingglass within't, for I hate glasses
As naturally, as some do cats, or cheese.

sp.speaker: Bev.
sp.l: In, in, there's none.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Who now? Is the ass past?

sp.speaker: Bev.
sp.l: I turned him up, ha, ha, ha, I fear he'll fall a working.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Second me handsomely, we'll entertain him
An hour or two, and laugh and get his clothes
To make our sport up. Wife, where's the empty hogshead
That wont to stand under the stairs?

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.l: There still.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Out with it quickly: I must have it filled.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.l: Not today, good sir, tomorrow will serve as well.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: I must have't now.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.l: 'Tis more than I can carry.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: I'll help thee: so, so. Foh! this vessel's musty.
Fetch out some water.

sp.speaker: Bev.
sp.l: Fetch't yourself.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Pox of all transmutation, I am smothered.
Lady, as you love me, give the hogshead vent.
The beer that's in't will work and break the vessel.

sp.speaker: Bev.
sp.l: Signior Antonio, as you love your life
Lie still and close, for if you stir you die.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: So, so, now shake it, so, so.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: O I am drowned, I drown!

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Whence comes this hollow sound?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: I drown, I smother!

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: My life 'tis Trincalo, for I have heard that coxcomb,
That ass, that clown, seeks to corrupt my wife,
Sending his fruit and dainties from the country.
O that 'twere he. How would I use the villain!
First crop his ears, then slit his nose, and geld him,
And with a red hot iron sear his raw wounds;
Then barrel him again, and send the eunuch
To the great Turk to keep his concubines. Tick, tock, who's within here?

sp.speaker: Bev.
sp.l: One that you dare not touch.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: One that I dare not?
Out villain, out. Signior Antonio!
Had it been any but yourself, he had died.
But as you saved my life before you went,
So now command mine in your services ▪
I would have sworn y'ad drowned in Barbary.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: 'Twas a hard passage: but not so dangerous
as was this vessel. Pray you conceive no ill,
I meant no harm, but called at your wife to know
How my son Lelio did, and daughter Flavia.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Sir I believe you.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: But I must tell you one thing,
You must not be so jealous, on my honour
She's very honest.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: For you I make no question.
But there's a rogue called Trincalo, whom if I catch.
I'll teach him.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Who? you mean Pandolfo's farmer.
Alas poor fool, he's a stark ass, but harmless.
And though she talk with him, 'tis but to laugh,
As all the world does at him: come be friends
At my entreaty.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Sir, for your sake.

sp.speaker: Be.
sp.l: I thank you.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Let's have a fire; and while I dry myself,
Provide good wine and meat. I'll dine with you.
I must not home thus wet. I am something bold with you.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: My house and self are at your service.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Lead in.
Alas poor, Trincalo hadst thou been taken,
Thou hadst been turned for Turkey. Ha; ha, ha; fair fall Antonio's shape.
What a notorious wittol's this! Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Antonio.
sp.l: Thus by great favour of propitious stars,
From fearful storms, shipwreck, and raging billows,
Merciless jaws of death, am I returned
To th'safe and quiet bosom of my country,
And wished embracements of my friends and kindred.
The memory of these misfortunes past,
Seasons the welcome, and augments the pleasure
I shall receive of my son Lelio ▪
And daughter Flavia. So doth alloy
make gold, that else were useless, serviceable.
So th'rugged forehead of a threatening mountain,
Threatens the smoothness of a smiling valley.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: What do I see? Is not this Trincalo
Transformed t'antonio? 'tis: and so perfectly
That did the right Antonio now confront him,
I'd swear they both were true, or both were false.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: This man admires the unexpectedness
Of my return.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: O wondrous power of stars,
And skill of art t'apply 't. You that are married
May justly fear, lest this astrologer
Cloth your wife's servants in your shape, and use you
As Jupiter did Amphitrio: you that are rich,
In your own form may lose your gold.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis Cricca.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: He seems so just the man he represents,
That I dare hardly use him as I purposed.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Cricca, well met, how fares my friend Pandolfo?

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Your friend Pandolfo? How are your means improved;
To style familiarly your master friend?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What sayest thou?

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: That I rejoice your worship's safe returned
From your late drowning. Th'exchange hath given you lost.
And all your friends worn mourning three months past.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: The danger of the shipwreck I escaped
So desperate was, that I may truly say
I am new born, not saved.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, through what a grace
And goodly countenance, the rascal speaks?
What a grave portance? Could Antonio
Himself outdo him? O you notorious villain!
Who would have thought thou couldst have thus dissembled?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How now? A servant thus familiar? Sirrah
Use your companions so: more reverence
Becomes you better.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: As though I understood not,
the end of all this plot and goodly business?
Come I know all, see! this untiled clod of earth
Conceits his mind transformed, as well as body.
He wrings and bites his lips for fear of laughing. Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why laugh you sirrah?

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Sirrah, to see thee changed
So strangely, that I can not spy one inch
Of thy old clownish carcase. Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Laughter proceeds
From absurd actions that are harmless.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.
Sententious blockhead!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And you're ill advised
To jest instead of pity. Alas! my miseries,
Dangers of death, slavery of cruel Moors,
And tedious journeys, might have easily altered
A stronger body; much more this decayed vessel,
Outworn with age, and broken by misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Leave your set speeches. Go to Antonio's house,
Effect your business. For upon my credit
Thou'rt so well turned, they dare not but accept thee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Where should I hope for welcome, if not there;
From my own house, children, and family?

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Is't possible this. Coxcomb should conceive
His mind transformed? How gravely he continues
The countenance he began? Ha, ha. Why blockhead?
Thinkest to deceive me too? Why Trincalo?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I understand you not. Hands off.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Art not thou Trincalo,
Pandolfo's man?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I not so much as know him.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Darest thou denie't to me?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I dare, and must
To all the world, 'long as Antonio lives.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: You arrant ass, have not I known thee serve
My master in his farm this thirteen years?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: By all the oaths that bind men's consciences
To truth, I am Antonio; and no other.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: What means this noise? O Cricca! what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Sir here's your farmer Trincalo, transformed
so just, as he were melted, and new cast
In the true mould of old Antonio.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Th'right eye's no liker to the left, than he
To my good neighbour. Divine Albumazar!
How I admire thy skill! just so he looked,
And thus he walked; this is his face, his hair,
His eyes, and countenance; if his voice be like
Then is th'astrologer a wonder-worker.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Signior Pandolfo, I thank the heavens as much
To find you well, as for my own return.
How does your daughter, and my love, Sulpitia?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Well, well, sir.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: This is a good beginning,
How naturally the rogue dissembles it?
With what a gentle garb, and civil grace
He speaks and looks: how cunningly Albumazar
Hath for our purpose suited him in Barbary clothes. I'll try him further: sir,
We heard you were drowned, pray you, how 'scaped you shipwreck?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: No sooner was I shipped for Barbary,
But fair wind followed, and fair weather led us.
When entered in the straits of Gibraltar,
The heavens, and seas, and earth, conspired against us,
The tempest tore our helm, and rent our tackles,
Broke the main mast, while all the sea about us
Stood up in watery mountains to overwhelm us.
And struck's against a rock, splitting the vessel
T'a thousand splinters. Ay, with two mariners
Swam to the coast, where by the barbarous Moors
We were surprised, fettered, and sold for slaves.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: This tale th'astrologer penned, and he hath conned it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But by a gentleman of Italy
Whom I had known before.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: No more, this taste
Proves thou canst play the rest. For this fair story
My hand I make thy ten pound, twenty marks.
Thou lookest and speak'st so like Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Whom should I look, and speak like, but myself?

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Good still ▪

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: But now my honest Trincalo,
Tell me, where's all the plate, the gold, and jewels,
that the astrologer, when he had transformed thee
Committed to thy charge? are they safe locked?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I understand you not.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: The jewel's man,
The plate and gold th'astrologer that changed thee
Bade thee lay up?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What plate? what gold? what jewels.
What transformation? what astrologer?

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Leave of Antonio now, and speak like Trincalo.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Leave of your jesting; it neither fits your place
Nor age, Pandolfo, to scoff your ancient friend.
I know not what you mean by gold and jewels,
Nor by th'astrologer, nor Trincalo.

sp.speaker: Cric.
sp.l: Better and better still. Believe me sir,
He thinks himself Antonio, and ever shall be,
And so possess your plate. Art not thou Trincalo
My master's farmer?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am Antonio
Your master's friend, if he teach you more manners.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Humour of wiving's gone: farewell good Flavia,
Three thousand pound must not be lost so slightly.
Come sir, we'll drag you to th'astrologer,
And turn you to your ragged bark of yeomanry.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: To me these terms!

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Come I'll not lose my plate.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Stay, sir, and take my counsel. Let him still
Firmly conceit himself the man he seems:
Thus he himself deceived, will far more earnestly
Effect your business, and deceive the rest.
There's a main difference twixt a self-bred action
And a forced carriage. Suffer him then to enter
Antonio's house: and wait th'event: for him
He cannot scape: what you intend to do,
Do't when 'Has served your turn. I see the maid,
Let's hence lest they suspect our consultations.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Thy counsel's good: away.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Look Trincalo
Yonder's your beauteous mistress Armellina,
And daughter Flavia. Courage, I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Blessed be the heavens, that rid me of this trouble.
For with their farmer and astrologer,
Plate, and gold, they've almost madded me.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Armellina?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Mistress.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Is the door fast?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Yes, as an usurer's purse.

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.l: Come hither wench.
Look here, there's Trincalo, Pandolfo's farmer
Wrapped in my father's shape: prithee come quickly,
And help me to abuse him.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Notorious clown!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: These are my gates, and that's the cabinet
That keeps my jewels, Lelio, and his sister.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Never was villainy so personate
In seemly properties of gravity.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Tick, tock.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Who's he that knocks so boldly?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: What want you, sir?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: O my fair daughter Flavia! Let all the stars
Pour down full blessings on thee. Open the doors.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Mark! his fair daughter Flavia ha, ha, ha.
Most shameless villain how he counterfeits!

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Know'st not thy father, old Antonio?
Is all the world grown frantic?

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.l: What Antonio?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Thy loving father, Flavia.

sp.speaker: Fl.
sp.l: My father!
Would thou wert in his place. Antonio's dead,
Dead, under water drowned.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: That dead and drowned
Am I.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: I love not to converse with dead men.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Open the door sweet Flavia.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Sir I am afeared:
Horror encloses me, my hairs stand up,
I sweat to hear a dead man speak, you smell
Of putrefaction: fie I feel't hither.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Thou'rt much abused, I live: come down, and know me.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Mistress let me have some sport too. Who's there?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Let me come in.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Soft, soft sir, you're too hasty.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Quickly, or else —

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Good words, good words, I pray sir,
In stranger's houses! were the doors your own,
You might be bolder.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I'll beat the doors and windows
About your ears.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Are you so hot? we'll cool you.
Since your late drowning, your grey and reverent head
is smeared with oes, and stuck with cockleshells,
This is to wash it.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Impudent whore!

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Out carter.
Hence dirty whipstock, hence you foul clown: be gone,
Or all the water I can make, or borrow,
Shall once more drown you.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Armellina? whom do you draw your tongue upon so sharply?

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Sir, 'tis your father's ghost, that strives by force
To break the doors and enter.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: This his grave looks!
In every lineament himself no liker.
Had I not haply been advertized,
What could have forced me think 'twere Trincalo?
Doubtless, th'astrologer hath raised a ghost
That walks in th'reverend ghost of my dead father.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: These ghosts, these Trincalo's, and astrologers,
Strike me beside myself. Who will receive me
When mine own son refuseth? O Antonio!

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Infinite power of art! who would believe
The planet's influence could transform a man
To several shapes! I could now beat him soundly
But that he wears the awful countenance
Of my dead father, whose memory I reverence.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: If I be changed beyond thy knowledge, son,
Consider that th'excess of heat in Barbary,
The fear of shipwreck, and long tedious journeys,
Have tanned my skin, and shrunk my eyes and cheeks;
Yet still this face, though altered, may be known.
This scar bears witness, 'twas the wound thou curedst
With thine own hands.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: He that changed Trincalo
To Antonio's figure, omitted not the scar
As a main character.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I have no other marks
Or reasons to persuade thee; methinks , this word
I am thy father, were argument sufficient
to bend my knees, and creep to my embracements.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: A sudden coldness strikes me, my tender heart
Beats with compassion of I know not what.
Sirrah be gone, truss up your goodly speeches,
Sad shipwracks, and strange transformations.
Your plot's discovered, 'twill not take: thy impudence
For once I pardon. The pious reverence.
I owe to th'grave resemblance of my father
Holds back my angry hands. Hence, if I catch you
Haunting my doors again, I'll bastonado you
Out of Antonio's skin. Away.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I go sir,
And yield to such cross fortune as thus drives me.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: When this transformed substance of my carcase
Did live imprisoned in a wanton hogshead,
My name was don Antonio, and that title
Preserved my life, and changed my suit of clothes.
sp.p: How kindly the good gentlewoman used me! with what respect and careful tenderness! Your worship sit had ever a sickly constitution, and I fear much more now since your long travail ▪ as you love me, off with these wet things, and put on the suit you left with me before you went to Barbary. Good sir neglect not your health: for upon my experience there's nothing worse for the rheum, than to be drenched in a musty hogshead. Pretty soul ▪ such another speech would have drawn off my legs and arms, as easily as hose and doublet. Had I been Trincalo I'd have sworn th'had cheated. But fie! 'tis base and clownish to suspect, and a gentlewoman's freeness to part with a cast suit. Now to the business. I'll in to my own house, and first bestow Armellina upon Trincalo, then try what can be done for Pandolfo: for 'tis a rule I wont t'observe. First do your own affairs, and next your masters. This word master makes me doubt I am not changed as I should be. But all's one, I'll venture, and do something worthy Antonio's name while I have it.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Wretched Antonio, hast been preserved so strangely
From foreign miseries to be wronged at home?
Barred from thy house by th'scorns of thine own children?

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.l: Tick, tock.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: But stay, there's on knocks boldly, may be some friend.

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.l: Tick, tock.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Dwell you here gentleman?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: He calls me gentleman.
See th'virtue of good clothes: all men salute,
Honour, respect and reverence us.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Young gentleman,
Let me without offence entreat your name,
And why you knock.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: How sirrah saucebox, my name?
Or thou some stranger art, or grossly ignorant
That knowest not me. Ha! what art thou that askest it?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Be not in choler sir.

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.l: Befits it me,
A gentleman of public reputation,
To stoop so low as satisfy the questions
Of base and earthly pieces like thyself? What art thou? ha?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Th'unfortunate possessor of this house.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Thou liest base sycophant, my worship owes it.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: 'May be my son hath sold it in my absence,
Thinking me dead. How long hast called you master?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: 'Long as Antonio possessed it.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Which Antonio?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Antonio Anastasio.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: That Anastasio
That drowned in Barbary?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: That Anastasio,
That self same man am I: I scaped by swimming,
And now return to keep my former promise
Of Flavia to Pandolfo; and in exchange,
To take Sulpitia to my wife.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: All this
I intended 'fore I went; but sir, if I
Can be noother than myself, and you
Are that Antonio, you and I are one.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: How? one with thee? speak such another syllable,
And by the terror of this deadly steel,
that ne'er saw light, but sent to endless darkness
All that durst stand before't: thou diest.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Alas
My weakness grown by age, and pains of travel,
Disarms my courage to defend myself;
I have no strength but patience.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: What art now?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Peter, and Thomas, William, what you please.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: What boldness madded thee to steal my name?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Sir, heat of wine.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: And sirrah when you're drunk,
Is there no person to put on, but mine,
To cover your intended villainies?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: But good sir, if I be not I, who am I?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: An ox, an ass, a dog.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Strange negligence
To lose myself! methinks I live and move,
Remember. Could the fearful apprehension
Of th'ugly fear of drowning so transform me?
Or did I die, and by Pythagoras' rule,
My soul's provided of another lodging?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Be what thou wilt, except Antonio,
'Tis death to touch that name.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Dangers at sea
Are pleasures, weighed with these home-injuries.
Was ever man thus scared beside himself?
O most unfortunate Antonio!
At sea thou suffered'st shipwreck of thy goods,
At land of thine own self. Antonio?
Or what name else they please? fly, fly to Barbary,
And rather there endure the foreign cruelty
Of fetters, whips, and Moors, then here at home
Be wronged and baffled by thy friends and children.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: How? prating still? why Timothy, be gone,
Or draw, and lay Antonio down betwixt us,
Let fortune of the fight decide the question.
Here's a brave rogue, that in the King's highway
Offers to rob me of my good name. Draw.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: These wrongs recall my strength ▪ I am resolved.
Better die once, then suffer always. Draw.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Stay. Understandest thou well nice points of duel?
Art born of gentle blood, and pure descent?
Was none of all thy lineage hanged, or cuckold?
Bastard, or bastinadoed? is thy pedigree
As long and wide as mine? For otherwise
Thou wert most unworthy; and 'twere loss of honour
In me to fight. More, I have drawn five teeth:
If thine stand sound, the terms are much unequal.
And by strict laws of duel, I am excused
To fight on disadvantage.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: This some ass!

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: If we concur in all, write a formal challenge,
And bring thy second: meanwhile I'll make provision
Of Calais sand to fight upon securely. Ha!

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Am I awake? or do deceitful dreams
Present to my wild fancy things I see not?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Sir, what amazement's this? why wonder you?

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Seest thou not Trincalo and Antonio?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: O strange! they're both here.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Didst not thou inform me,
That Trincalo was turned t'antonio?
Which I believing, like a cursed son,
With most reproachful threats, drove mine old father
From his own doors; and yet rest doubtful, whether
This be the true Antonio: 'May be th'astrologer
Hath changed some other, and not Trincalo.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: No, fear it not: 'tis plain: Albumazar
Hath cheated my old master of his plate.
For here's the farmer, as like himself as ever;
Only his clothes excepted. Trincalo!

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Cricca, where's Trincalo? dost see him here?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Yes, and as rank an ass as e'er he was.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Thou'rt much deceived, thou neither seest nor knowest me.
I am transformed, transformed.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Thou'rt still thyself.
Lelio, this farmer's half a fool, half knave.
And as Pandolfo did with much entreaty
persuade him to transform; so as much labour
Will hardly bring the coxcomb to himself,
That ne'er was out on't. Who art, if not he?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: My name is don Antonio, I am now going
To my own house, to give Pandolfo Flavia,
And Armellina to his farmer Trincalo.
How dar'st thou Cricca, but a meaner servant,
Resemble me, a man of worth and worship,
To such a clown as Trincalo, a branded fool,
An ass, a laughingstock to town and country?
Art not ashamed to name him with Antonio?

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Do not thy actions, with thy rude behaviour,
Proclaim thee what thou art?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Notorious clown!

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Villain, thou'st broke my shoulders.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: O didst feel him?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: I with a pox.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Then thou'rt still Trincalo.
For hadst thou been Antonio, he had smarted.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: I feel it as I am Antonio.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Fool! who loves Armellina?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: 'Tis I, 'tis I.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Antonio never loved his kitchenmaid.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Well, I was taken for Antonio,
And in his name received ten pound in gold,
Was by his mistress entertained; but thou
Enviest my happiness: if thou'st th'ambition
To rise as I have done: go to Albumazar,
And let him change thee to a knight, or lord.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Note the strange power of strong imagination.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: A world of engines cannot wrest my thoughts,
From being a gentleman: I am one, and will be:
And though I be not, yet will think myself so:
And scorn thee Cricca, as a slave and servant.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: 'Tis but lost labour to dissuade his dulness,
Believe me that's your father.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: When I drove him thence,
spite of my blood his reverent countenance
Struck me t'a deep compassion. To clear all,
I'll ask one question. Signior Antonio,
What money took you when you went your voyage?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: As I remember, fourscore and fifteen pound
In Barbary gold. Had Lucio kept his word
I had carried just a hundred.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Pardon me, father;
'Twas my blind ignorance, not want of duty,
That wronged you: all was intended for a farmer,
Whom an astrologer, they said, transformed.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: How an astrologer?

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: When you parted hence
It seems you promised Flavia to Pandolfo.
News of your death arriving, th'old gentleman
Importunes me to second what you purposed.
Consulting therefore with my friends and kindred,
Loath my young sister should be buried quick
I'th grave of threescore years: by their advice
I fully did deny him. He chafes and storms,
And finds at length a cunning man, that promised
To turn his farmer to your shape: and thus
Possess your house, and give him Flavia.
Whereof I warned, wronged you in stead of Trincalo.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Then hence it came they called me Trincalo,
And talked of an astrologer; which names
Almost enraged me passed myself and senses.
'Tis true I promised, but have oft repented it.
And much more since he goes about to cheat me.
He must not have her, sir.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: I am glad you're so resolved.
And since, with us, you find that match unequal,
Let's all entreat you to bestow your daughter
Upon his son Eugenio.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Son, at your pleasure
Dispose of Flavia, with my full consent.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: And as you judge him worthy your daughter Flavia,
Think me no less of his Sulpitia.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I do; and ever had desire to match
Into that family; and now I find myself
Old, weak, unfit for marriage, you shall enjoy her,
if I can work Pandolfo by entreaty:

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: To deal with him with reason and entreaties,
Is to persuade a madman: for his love
Makes him no less. All speeches opposite
T'his fixed desire, and love-corrupted judgement,
Seem extreme fooleries. Will he consent
To give his daughter to your son, and you
Deny him Flavia? Shall Eugenio
Expect or land or love from old Pandolfo,
Being his open rival? 'tis impossible.
He sought to cozen you; therefore resolve
To pay him in's own money. Be but advised
By my poor counsel, and one stroke shall cut
The root of his designs, and with his arrows
Strike his own plot so dead, that Albumazar
With all his stars and instruments, shall never
Give it fresh motion.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Cricca, to thy direction
We yield ourselves, manage us at thy pleasure.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Speak quickly Cricca.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: The ground of all this business,
Is to catch Trincalo, and lock him fast
Till I release him: next, that no man whisper
Th'least word of your return. Then will I home,
And with a cheerful look tell my old master,
That Trincalo — but stay, look where he comes,
Let's in, and there at leisure I'll inform you
From point to point. Lelio, detain him here,
Till I send Armellina down to second you.
Cross him in nothing, call him Antonio,
And good enough.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Fear not, let me alone.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: This rascal Cricca with his arguments
Of malice, so disturbs my gentle thoughts,
That I half doubt I am not what I seem:
but that will soon be cleared; if they receive me
In at Antonio's house, I am Antonio.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Signior Antonio my most loving father?
Blessed be the day and hour of your return.

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.l: Son Lelio? A blessing on my child, I pray thee tell me,
How fares my servant Armellina? well?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Have you forgotten my sister Flavia?

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.l: What my dear daughter Flavia? no, but first
Call Armellina: for this day we'll celebrate
A gleek of marriages: Pandolfo and Flavia,
Sulpitia and myself, and Trincalo
With Armellina. Call her, good Lelio, quickly.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: So: this is well that Lelio
Confesseth me his father. Now I am perfect,
Perfect Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Signior Antonio!
My long expected master!

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: O Armellina!
Come let me kiss thy brow like my own daughter.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Sir 'tis too great a favour. I kiss your foot.
What fallen? Alas! how feeble you are grown,
With your long travel?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: True; and being drowned,
Nothing so grieved me as to lose thy company.
But since I am safe returned, for thy good service
I'll help thee to a husband.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: A husband, sir?
Some young and lusty youth, or else I'll none.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: To one that love's thee dear, dear wench.
A goodly man, like me in limbs and fashion.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Fie, an old man? how? cast myself away,
And be no nurse but his?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: He's not like me
In years and gravity, but fair proportion.
A handsome well-set man as I.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: His name?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: 'Tis Tom Trincalo of Totnam,

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Signior Pandolfo's lusty farmer?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: That's he.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Most unexpected happiness! 'tis the man,
I more esteem then my own life: sweet master
Procure that match, and think me satisfied
For all my former service without wages.
But as I fear you jest. My poor unworthiness
Hope's not so great a fortune as sweet Trincalo.
No, wretched Armellina, in and despair:
Back to thy mournful dresser; there lament
Thy flesh to kitchen-stuff, and bones to ashes,
For love of thy sweet farmer.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Alas poor soul,
How prettily she weeps for me! Wilt see him?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: My soul waits in my eyes, and leaves my body
Senseless.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Then swear to keep my counsel.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I swear
By th'beauteous eyes of Trincalo.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Why I am Trincalo.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Your worship sir! why do you flout your servant,
Right worshipful Antonio, my reverend master?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Pox of Antonio, I am Tom Trincalo.
Why laughest thou?

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: 'Tis desire and joy,
To see my sweetest.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Look upon me and see him.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: I say I see Antonio, and none other.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: I am within, thy love; without, thy master.
Th'astrologer transformed me for a day.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: Mock not your poor maid, pray you sir.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: I do not.
Now would I break this head against the stones,
To be unchanged; fie on this gentry, it stick's
Like birdlime, or the pox. I can not part with't.
Within, I am still thy farmer Trincalo.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Then must I wait, till old Antonio
Be brought to bed of a fair Trincalo;
Or flay you, and strip you to yourself again.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Carry me to your chamber. Try me there.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: O sir by no means: but with my lovely farmer
I'd stay all night and thank him.

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.l: Cross misfortune!
Accursed Albumazar! and mad Pandolfo!
To change me thus, that when I most desire
To be myself, I cannot. Armellina!
Fetch me a lookingglass.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: To what end?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Fetch one.
Let my old master's business sink or swim,
This sweet occasion must not be neglected.
Now shall I know th'astrologers's skill: o wonderful!
Admired Albumazar in two transmutations:
Here's my old farmer's face. How in an instant
I am unchanged that was so long a changing. Here's my flat nose again, etc.
Now Armellina take thy loved Trincalo
To thy desired embracements, use thy pleasure,
Kiss him thy bellyful.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Not here in public.
T'enjoy too soon what pleaseth is unpleasant:
The world would envy that my happiness.
Go in, I'll follow you, and in my bedchamber
We'll consummate the match in privacy.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Was not the face I wore, far worse than this?
But for thy comfort, wench, Albumazar
Hath died my thoughts so deep i'th' grain of gentry,
'Tis not a glass can rob me of my good fashion,
And gentlemanly garb. Follow, my dear.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I'll follow you. So, now you're fast enough.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Help Armellina, help! I am fallen i'th' cellar:
Bring a fresh plantain leaf, I have broke my shin.

sp.speaker: Arm.
sp.l: Thus have I caught m'a husband in a trap,
And in good earnest mean to marry him.
'Tis a tough clown and lusty: he works day and night;
And rich enough for me, that have no portion
But my poor service. Well: he's something foolish;
The better can I domineer, and rule him
At pleasure. That's the mark, and utmost height
We women aim at. I am resolved; I'll have him.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: In, Armellina, lock up Trincalo.

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.l: I will, sir.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Cricca, for this thy counsel, if't succeed,
Fear not thy master's anger: I'll prefer thee
and count thee as my genius, or good fortune.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: It can not choose but take. I know his humour;
And can at pleasure feather him with hopes,
Making him fly what pitch I wish, and stoop
When I show foul.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: But for the suit of clothes?

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: I'll throw them o'er your garden wall. Away.
Hast to Eugenio, and Sulpitia,
Acquaint them with the business.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: I go.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: The hopeful issue of thy counsel, Cricca,
Brightens this evening, and makes it more excel
The clearest day, than a grey morning doth
The blindest midnight: raising my amorous thoughts
To such a pitch of joy, that riches, honour,
And other pleasures, to Sulpitia's love,
Appear like molehills to the moon.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: Lelio?

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: O there's the voice that in one note contains
All cords of music: how gladly she'll embrace
The news I give her, and the messenger!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: Soft, soft, you're much mistaken: for in earnest,
I am angry Lelio; and with you.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Sweetest, those flames
Rise from the sire of love, and soon will quench
I'th' welcome news I bring you.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: Stand still I charge you
By th'virtue of my lips; speak not a syllable
As you expect a kiss should close my choler.
For I must chide you.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: O my Sulpitia,
Were every speech a pistol charged with death,
I'd stand them all in hope of that condition.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: First, sir, I hear, you teach Eugenio
Too grave a wariness in your sister's love,
And kill his honest forwardness of affection
With your far-fet respects, suspicions, fears.
You have your may-be's; this is dangerous:
that course were better: for if so: and yet:
Who knows? th'event is doubtful: be advised:
'Tis a young rashness: your father is your father:
Take leisure to consider. Thus you've considered
Poor Flavia almost to her grave. Fie Lelio,
Had this my smallness undertook the business,
And done no more in four short winter days
Than you in four months, I'd have vowed my maidenhead
To th'living tomb of a sad nunnery.
Which for your sake I loathe.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Sweet by your favour

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: Peace! peace! Now you're so wise as if y'had eaten
Nothing but brains, and marrow of Machiavell.
You tip your speeches with Italian motti,
Spanish refrains, and English quoth he's. Believe me
There's not a proverb salts your tongue, but plants
Whole colonies of white hairs. O what a business
These hands must have when you have married me,
To pick out sentences that over-year you.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: Give me but leave.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: Have I a lip? and you
Made sonnets on't? 'tis your fault, for otherwise,
Your sister and Eugenio had been sure
Long time ere this.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: But —

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: Stay, your cue's not come yet.
I hate as perfectly this gray-green of yours,
As old Antonio's greene-gray. Fie! Wise lovers,
Are most absurd. Were not I full resolved,
I should begin to cool mine own affection.
For shame consider well your sister's temper.
Her melancholy may much hurt her. Respect her,
Or spite of mine own love, I'll make you stay
Six months, before you marry me. Lelio whispers.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: This your so happy news? returned? and safe?
Antonio yet alive? Lelio whispers.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: And then?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: Well. All your business must be compassed
With winding plots, and cunning stratagems.
Look to't: for if we be not married ere next morning,
By the great love that's hid in this small compass,
Flavia and myself will steal you both away
To your eternal shame and foul discredit.

sp.speaker: Lel.
sp.l: How prettily this lovely littleness,
In one breath pleads her own cause, and my sister's;
Chides me, and loves. This is that pleasing temper
I more admire, than a continued sweetness
That oversatisfies: 'tis salt I love; not sugar.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: How? not a single share of this great prize,
That have deserved the whole? was't not my plot,
And pains, and you mere instruments and porters?
Shall I have nothing?

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: No, not a silver spoon.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: Nor cover of a trencher-salt.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Nor table-napkin ▪

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Friends; we have kept an honest trust and faith
'Long time amongst us ▪ break not that sacred league,
By raising civil theft ▪ turn not your fury
'Gainst your own bowels. Rob your careful master!
Are you not ashamed?

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: 'Tis our profession,
As yours astrology. And in th'days of old,
Good morrow thief, as welcome was received,
As now your worship. 'tis your own instruction.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: The Spartans held it lawful, and th'arabians,
So grew Arabia, happy: Sparta, valiant.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: The world's a theater of theft: great rivers
Rob smaller brooks; and them the ocean.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Have not I weaned you up from petty-larceny,
Dangerous and poor? and nursed you to full strength
Of safe and gainful theft? By rules of art
And principles of cheating, made you as free
from taking, as you went invisible?
And do ye thus requite me? this the reward
For all my watchful care?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: We are your scholars,
Made by your help, and our own aptness, able
To instruct others. 'tis the trade we live by.
You that are servant to divine astrology,
Do something worth her livery. Cast figures,
Make almanacs for all Meridian's.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: Sell perspicils, and instruments of hearing,
Turn clowns to gentlemen, buzzards to falcons,
Cur-dogs to greyhounds, kitchenmaids to ladies.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Discover more new stars, and unknown planets:
Vent them by dozens, style them by the names
Of men that buy such ware. Take lawful courses,
Rather than beg.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Not keep your honest promise?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: Believe none, credit none: for in this city
No dwellers are, but cheaters, and cheatees.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: You promised me the greatest share.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Our promise!
If honest men by obligations,
And instruments of law, are hardly constrained
T'observe their word; can we, that make profession
Of lawless courses, do't?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Amongst ourselves.
Falcons that tyrannize o'er weaker fowl,
Hold peace with their own feathers.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: But when they counter
Upon one quarry, break that league as we do.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: At least restore ten pound in gold I lent you.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: 'Twas lent in an ill second, worser third,
And luckless fourth: 'tis lost, Albumazar.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: Saturn was in ascension. Mercury
Was then combust when you delivered it.
'Twill never be restored.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Hali, Abenezra,
Hiarcha, Brachman, Budda Babylonicus,
And all the Chaldes and the cabalists,
Affirm that sad aspect threats loss of debts.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Frame by your azimuth and almicantarat,
An engine like a mace, whose quality
Of strange retractive virtue may recall
desperate debts, and with that undo sergeants.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.l: Was ever man thus baited by's own whelps?
Give me a slender portion for a stock
To begin trade again.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: 'Tis an ill course
And full of fears. This treasure hath enriched us,
And given us means to purchase, and live quiet
Of th'fruit of dangers past. When I used robbing,
All blocks before me looked like constables,
And posts appeared in shape of gallows.
Therefore good tutor take your pupil's counsel:
'Tis better beg than steal: live in poor clothes,
Then hang in satin.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Villains, I'll be revenged,
And reveal all the business to a justice.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Do, if thou longest to see thy own anatomy.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: This treachery persuades me to turn honest.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.l: Search your nativity: see if the fortunates
And luminaries be in a good aspect.
And thank us for thy life. Had we done well,
We had cut thy throat ere this.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Albumazar,
Trust not these rogues; hence and revenge.

sp.speaker: Ron.
sp.l: Fellows away, here's company. Let's hence. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Now Cricca, mask thy countenance in joy,
Speak welcome language of good news, and move
Thy master, whose desires are credulous,
To believe what thou givest him. If thy design
Land at the haven 'tis bound for; then Lelio,
Eugenio, and their mistresses, are obliged
By oath, t'assure a state of forty pounds
Upon thee for thy life.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I long to know
How my good farmer speeds; how Trincalo
Hath been received by Lelio.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Where shall I find him?
What we most seek, still flies us; what's avoided,
Follows, or meets us full. I am embossed
with trotting all the streets to find Pandolfo,
And bless him with good news.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: This haste of Cricca
Abodes some good; doubtless my Trincalo,
Received for Antonio, hath given me Flavia.
Cricca?

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Neither in Paul's, at home, nor in th'exchange?
Nor where he uses to converse? he's lost:
And must be cried.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Turn hither, Cricca: Cricca,
Seest me not?

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Sir, the news, and haste to tell it,
Had almost blinded me. 'tis so fortunate,
I dare not pour it all at once upon you,
Lest you should faint and swoon away with joy.
Your transformed Trincalo -

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: What news of him?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Entered as owner in Antonio's house -

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: On.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Is acknowledged by his daughter Flavia,
And Lelio, for their father.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Quickly good Cricca!

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: And hath sent me in haste to bid you -

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Come with your son Eugenio. -

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: And then?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: That he may be a witness of your marriage.
But sir, I see no signs of so large gladness
As I expected, and this news deserved.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: 'Tis here, 'tis here, within. All outward symptoms
And characters of joy, are poor expressions
Of my great inward happiness: my heart's full,
And cannot vent the passions. Run Cricca, run,
Run, as thou lovest me, call Eugenio,
And work him to my purpose thou canst do it.
Haste, call him instantly.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: I fly sir.

sp.speaker: Pandolfo.
sp.l: How shall I recompense this astrologer?
This great Albumazar? through whose learned hands,
Fortune hath poured th'effect of my best wishes,
And crowned my hopes. Give him this chain? alas!
'tis a poor thanks, short by a thousand links
Of his large merit. No, he must live with me,
And my sweet Flavia, at his ease and pleasure,
Wanting for nothing. And this very night
I'll get a boy, and he erect a figure
To calculate his fortunes. So there's Trincalo
Antoniated, or Antonio intrinculate.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Signior Pandolfo! welcome.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Your servant sir.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Well met Antonio, my prayers and wishes
Have waited on you ever.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Thanks, dearest friend.
To speak my dangers past, were to discourse
Of dead men at a feast. Such sad relations
Become not marriages. Sir, I am here
Returned to do you service: where's your son?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: He'll wait upon you presently.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Signior Antonio!
Happily welcome.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Thanks Eugenio.
How think you gentlemen? were it amiss
To call down Flavia and Sulpitia,
That what we do, may with a full consent
Be entertained by all?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: 'Tis well remembered.
Eugenio, call your sister.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Lelio, call my daughter.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Wisely considered Trincalo: 'tis a fair prologue
To th' comedy ensuing. Now I confess
Albumazar had equal power to change,
And mend thy understanding with thy body.
Let me embrace and hug thee for this service.
'Tis a brave onset: ah my sweet Trincalo!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: How like you the beginning?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: 'Tis o'th further side
All expectation.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Was't not right? and spoken
Like old Antonio?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: 'Tis most admirable:
Were't he himself that spoke, he could not better't.
And for thy sake, I wish Antonio's shape
May ever be thy house, and's wit thy inmate.
But where's my plate, and cloth of silver?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Safe.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: They come: keep state, keep state, or all's discovered.

div.head: Act. 5. Scen. 6.
div.stage: Anto. Pand. Eug. Lel. Fla. sulp.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Eugenio, Flavia, Lelio, and Sulpitia ▪
Marriages once confirmed, and consummate,
Admit of no repentance. Therefore 'tis fitting
All parties with full freedom speak their pleasure,
Before it be too late.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Good! excellent!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Speak boldly therefore: do you willingly
Give full authority, that what I decree
Touching these businesses, you'll all perform?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I rest at your dispose: what you determine,
With my best power I ratify; and Sulpitia,
I dare be bold to promise, says no less.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: Whate'er my father, brother, and yourself
Shall think convenient pleaseth me.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: In this,
As in all other service, I commit myself
To your commands; and so I hope, my sister.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: With all obedience: sir dispose of me
As of a child, that judgeth nothing good
But what you shall approve.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: And you Pandolfo?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I most of all. And, for I know the minds
Of youth are apt to promise, and as prone
To repent after; 'tis my advice they swear
T'observe, without exception, your decree.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: Content.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: Content

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: By all the powers that hear
Oaths, and rain vengeance upon broken faith,
I promise to confirm and ratify
Your sentence.

sp.speaker: Le.
sp.l: Sir, I swear no less.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.l: The selfsame oath binds me.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.l: And me the same.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Now dear Antonio, all our expectation
Hangs at your mouth: none of us can appeal
From you to higher courts.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: First for preparative,
Or slight praeludium to the greater matches;
I must entreat you that my Armellina
Be matched with Trincalo. Two hundred crowns
I give her for her portion.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: 'Tis done. Some relics
Of his old clownery, and dregs o'th country,
Dwell in him still: how careful he provides
For himself first! Content. And more, I grant him
A lease of twenty pounds a year.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I thank you.
Gentlemen, since I feel myself much broken
With age, and my late miseries, and too cold
To entertain new heat; I freely yield
Sulpitia, whom I loved, to my son Lelio.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: How cunningly the farmer hath provided
T'observe the semblance of Antonio's person,
And keep himself still free for Armellina!

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Signior Pandolfo, you're wise, and understand
How ill hot appetites of unbridled youth
Become grey hairs. How grave and honourable
Were't for your age to be enamoured
With the fair shape of virtue, and the glory
Of your forefathers! Then would you blush to think
How by this dotage, and unequal love,
You stain their honour, and your own. Awake,
Banish those wild affections; and by my example
Turn t'your repose self.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: To what purpose, pray you
Serves this long proem? on to th'sentence.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Sir,
Conformity of years, likeness of manners,
Are Gordian knots that bind up matrimony.
Now betwixt seventy winters, and sixteen,
There's no proportion, nor least hope of love.
Fie, that a gentleman of your discretion,
crowned with such reputation in your youth,
Should in your western days, loose th'good opinion
Of all your friends; and run to th'open danger
Of closing the weak remnant of your days
With discontentment unrecoverable.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Wrack me no more: pray you let's hear the sentence.
Note how the ass would fright me, and endear
His service; intimating, that his power
May overthrow my hopes. Proceed to th'sentence.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: These things considered, I bestow my daughter
Upon your son Eugenio; whose constant love
With his so modest carriage, hath deserved her.
And, that you freeze not for a bedfellow,
I marry you with patience.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Treacherous villain!
Accursed Trincalo! I'll — but this no place,
He's too well backed. But shortly when the date
Of his antonioship's expired, revenge
Shall sweeten this disgrace.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Signior Pandolfo,
When you recover yourself, lost desperately
In disproportioned dotage, than you'll thank me
For this great favour: be not obstinate:
Disquiet not yourself.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Pandolfo.
sp.l: And that you freeze not for a bedfellow,
I marry you with patience. Traitorous villain!
Is't not enough to wrong me, and betray me,
But 't must be done with scoffs? accursed Trincalo!
And me most miserable! that when I thought
T'embrace young Flavia, see her before my face
Bestowed upon my son! my son my rival!
This is Eugenio's plot, and his friend Lelio's;
Who, with my servant Cricca, have conspired,
And suborned Trincalo to betray his master.
Why do I rage 'gainst any but myself,
That have committed such a serious business
To th'hands of a base clown, and ignorant?
I see mine error, but no means to help it.
Only the sweetness of revenge is left me,
Which I must execute: th'hours of's gentry
Are now clean spent. I'll home, and there attend him.

sp.speaker: Trincalo
sp.p: Welcome old trusty Trincalo, good farmer welcome! give me thy hand, we must not part hereafter. Fie, what a trouble 'tis to be out of a man's self! If gentlemen have no pleasure but what I felt today; a team of horses shall not drag me out of my profession. There's nothing amongst them but borrowing, compounding for half their debts, and have their purse cut for the rest, cozened by whores, frighted with husbands, washed in wet hogsheads, cheated of their clothes, and falling in cellars for conclusion.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: O precious piece of villainy! are you unchanged?
How confident the rogue dares walk the streets!

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.p: And then such quarrelling: never a suit I wore today, but hath been soundly basted. Only this faithful country case 'scaped fist-free; and be it spoken in a good hour, was never beaten yet since it came from fulling!

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Tiff. toff. Base treacherous villain! toff. toff. toff.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Is this the recompense of my day's work?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: You marry me to patience? there's patience.
And that you freeze not, there's warm patience,
She's a good bedfellow; have patience.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: You'll beat me out on't sir: how have I wronged you?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: So, as deserves th'expression of my fury
with th'cruelest tortures I can execute.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: You kill me sir.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Have patience.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Pray you sir!

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Seek not by humble penitence t'appease me.
Nothing can satisfy.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Farewell humility.
Now am I beaten sober. (Takes away Pandolfo's staff)
Shall age and weakness master my youth and strength?
Now speak your pleasure: what's my fault?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Darest deny
Thy own act done before so many witnesses?
Suborned by others, and betray my confidence
With such a stony impudence?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: I have been faithful
In all you trusted me.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: To them; not me.
O what a proem stuffed with grave advice,
And learned counsel, you could shower upon me
Before the thunder of your deadly sentence!
And give away my mistress with a scoff!

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: I give your mistress?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Didst not thou decree
Contrary t'our compact, against my marriage?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Why when was I your judge?

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Just now, here.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: See your error!
Then was I fast locked in Antonio's cellar:
Where making virtue of necessity,
I drunk stark drunk; and waking, found myself
Clothed in this farmer's suit, as in the morning.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Didst not thou swear t'enter Antonio's house,
And give me Flavia for my wife? and after,
Before my own face, gavest her to my son?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Canst thou deny't?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha! Whilst Trincalo laughs, and falls the staff, Pandolfo recovers it, and beats him.
Have you got mistress Patience? ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Is not this true?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Answer me.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha wan!

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Was't not thus?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: I answer. First, I never was transformed,
But guled, as you were, by th'astrologer
And those that called m'antonio. To prove this true,
The gentleman you spoke with, was Antonio,
The right Antonio, safely returned from Barbary.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Hey me! what's this?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Truth itself.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Was't not thou
That gavest the sentence?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Believe me no such matter:
I ne'er was gentleman, nor otherwise
than what I am, unless 'twere when I was drunk.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: How have I been deceived! good Trincalo
Pardon me. I have wronged thee.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Pardon you?
When you have beaten me to paste, good Trincalo
Pardon me?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I am sorry for't; excuse me.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: I am sorry I must excuse you. But I pardon you.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Now tell me where's the plate and cloth of silver,
The gold and jewels that th'astrologer
Committed to thy keeping?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.l: What plate, what jewels?
He gave me none. But when he went to change me,
After a thousand circles and ceremonies,
He binds me fast upon a form, and blinds me
With a thick table-napkin. Not long after
Unbinds my head and feet, and gives me light:
And then I plainly saw, that I saw nothing;
The parlour was clean swept of all was in't.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Ojh me? oi me!

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: What ails you? Sir, what ails you?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: I am undone, I have lost my love, my plate,
My whole estate, and with the rest myself.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Lose not your patience too. Leave this lamenting,
And lay the town; you may recover it.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: 'Tis to small purpose. In, and hold thy peace.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Where shall I find my master to content him
With welcome news? He's here; news! news!
News of good fortune, joy and happiness!

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Cricca, my sadness is uncapable
Of better tidings: I am undone most miserable!

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Offend not your good luck, you're now more fortunate
Than when you rose this morning: be merry, sir,
Cheer up yourself, you've what you wished, fear nothing.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: May be Antonio newly repents himself,
With purpose to restore my Flavia.
Cricca, what is't? where's all this happiness?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Locked in Antonio's closet.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: All alone?
Sure that's my Flavia. Is not Eugenio
Suffered to enter?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Antonio keeps the key:
No creature enters but himself. All's safe
And shall be so restored.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: O my sweet Cricca!

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: And they that wronged you, most extremely sorry,
Ready to yield you any satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Is't possible they should so soon repent them?
That injured me so lately? tell me the manner
That caused them see their error.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: I'll tell you, sir.
Being just now at old Antonio's house,
One thunder's at th'back door, enters, and presses
To speak in private with young Lelio;
Was instantly admitted: and think you who?
'Twas your astrologer Albumazar.
When he had spoke a while; Lelio and Antonio
In haste command 'Me fetch a constable.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: How can this story touch my happiness?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: I up and down throw slimy alehouses,
Cloudy tobacco-shops, and vapouring taverns:
My mouth full of enquiry; at last found one ▪

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: What of all this? is't possible a constable
Concerns my good?

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: And following my directions,
Went to a tippling-house, where we took drinking
Three handsome fellows with a great chest; attached them,
And brought all to Antonio.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.l: Well, what then?

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: These were th'astrologers intelligences.
That robbed you through th'south window.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: I thought th'hadst spoken
Of Flavia's restoring.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: I mean your plate
And treasure; pray you, sir, is't not great happiness
To reobtain three thousand pounds in value,
Desperately lost? and you still dote and dream
Of Flavia, who by your own consent
And oath is promised to your son Eugeni?

sp.speaker: Pa,
sp.l: Forward.

sp.speaker: Cr.
sp.l: Within this chest Antonio found your plate,
Gold, jewels, cloth of silver, nothing perished,
but all safe locked till you acknowledge it.
And since Albumazar of his own accord
Freely confessed, and safe restored your treasure:
Since 'tis a day of jubilee and marriage;
Antonio would entreat you to release
And pardon the astrologer: thanking your fortune
That hath restored you to your wealth, and self.
Both which were lost i'th' foolish love of Flavia.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.l: Reason hath cleared my sight, and drawn the veil
Of dotage that so darked my understanding.
I clearly see the slavery of affections;
And how unsuitable my declining years
Are for the dawning youth of Flavia.
Let the best joys of Hymen compass her,
And her young husband, my Eugenio,
With full content. And since Albumazar
By accident, caused all this happiness;
I freely pardon him, and his companions:
And hast t'assist the marriages and feasts.

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Why now you show yourself a worthy gentleman.

sp.speaker: Trin.
sp.l: Cricca I overheard your news: all parts are pleased ▪
Except myself. Is there no news for Trincalo?

sp.speaker: Cric.
sp.l: Know'st it not? In, and see: Antonio
Hath given thee Armellina with a portion,
Two hundreth crowns: and old Pandolfo bound
By oath t'assure thee twenty pounds a year,
For three lives.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: Haj!

sp.speaker: Cri.
sp.l: Come in.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: I'll follow.
Two hundred crowns? and twenty pound a year
For three good lives? Cargo! Hai Trincalo!
My wife's extremely busy, dressing the supper
For these great marriages; and I not idle,
So that I cannot entertain you here
As I would elsewhere. But if you come to Totnam
Some four days hence, and ask for Trincalo
At th'sign o'th hogshead; I'll mortgage all my lives
To bid you welcome. You that love Trincalo,
And mean to meet, clap hands and make't a bargain.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
